The government approved an amendment that will allow the Estonian–Latvian border to be crossed daily with the requirement of only one coronavirus test per week from Monday, 3 May, for work or study. The test must be negative or the person must be declared non-infectious. The rule applies to people who cross the Estonian–Latvian border more than twice a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210508191341/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/crossing-latvian-border-everyday-work-and-study-becomes-easier

No policy change. People from the European Union, the Schengen area, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and Vatican are allowed to travel to Estonia. Asymptomatic citizens of foreign states arriving in Estonia from states not named above are allowed to travel to Estonia for work or studies. Exemptions apply for people transporting goods and raw materials, people involved in international freight or passenger transport, people performing technical tasks for companies based in Estonia, providers of healthcare services, diplomats, people arriving for the purpose of international military cooperation and people with a special entry permission.    Upon arrival, travelers must quarantine for ten days. Anyone who does not wish to self-isolate for 10 days after their arrival in Estonia can take a PCR test abroad no earlier than 72 hours before their arrival in Estonia. While in Estonia, a second test can be taken no earlier than on the sixth day after the first test. The 10-day restrictions on movement period can be concluded earlier if both tests are negative. Anyone who has not taken a test up to 72 hours before their arrival in Estonia can take one immediately after their arrival and the second test no earlier than six days after their first test. The 10-day restrictions on movement period can be concluded earlier if both tests are negative. Quarantine restrictions do not apply to travelers who have had and recovered from Covid-19 within 6 months of travel or who have received the Covid-19 vaccination.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517192704/https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-self-isolation-requirements-passengers

In Helsinki, from 3rd May, Vocational schools and Upper Secondary Schools will transition to contact teaching.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210504002121/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/information/recommendations-and-restrictions/

Generally, in Finland, the regional restrictions and recommendations in place depend on the phase of the epidemic in the region in question. Some regions still recommend distance learning for some education levels while some have transitioned to contact learning with additional guidelines.    In South Finland, distance learning is recommended in universities and colleges. While upper secondary school, vocational education  and comprehensive education contact education is implemented with guidelines. https://archive.vn/BOLqW     In Kymenlaakso, Colleges are recommended to continue in distance learning. Absolutely necessary contact teaching can be carried out following the protection instructions. In secondary education (high schools and vocational training), there will be a shift to contact teaching, so that measures that promote safety, such as safety gaps, the use of masks and hygiene instructions, can be implemented.  https://archive.vn/a13Gm     In Länsi-Pohja Hospital District, Distance education is recommended for secondary schools according to the epidemic situation in the municipality. It is recommended that a maximum of six people participate in contact teaching situations at a time. Contact teaching must follow corona safety instructions and ensure adequate safety distances and the use of a mask. https://archive.vn/mrNRN     In Satakunta, ATTR recommends an alternating hybrid model of distance and contact teaching and Upper level, primary and Secondary education is continued in contact teaching. https://archive.vn/wkuMd     In Helsinki,  Upper comprehensive school grades 7–10, Upper secondary schools and Vocational schools transitioned to contact teaching on Monday 3 May. https://archive.vn/8IXr3     In South Karelia, The teaching of a civic college is suspended insofar as it is not possible to implement it as distance teaching. https://archive.vn/dIPQs

In areas such as East Savo Hospital District, contact teaching is in effect in primary, secondary and higher education institutions. https://archive.vn/kOfcI  However, some regions still require closing on some levels for example - In the Soite region, Coronavirus infections are currently mainly concentrated in young people aged 12–25, and therefore the authority task group recommends that all upper secondary schools in the Soite area switch to distance education next week (17–21.5.2021). The coronavirus situation has deteriorated rapidly, especially in Kannus, so students in grades 4–9 in Kannus’ primary schools switch to distance education for next week (17–21.5.2021). https://archive.vn/cLGbw . In Kymenlaakso, Remote learning should be continued at higher education institutions. https://archive.vn/lnVSk

On 22 April, the Government decided to extend the restrictions on entry into the country until 25 May 2021. The decisions will enter into force on 26 April.    Internal border traffic refers to traffic between Finland and other Schengen countries. Finland continues to restrict entry from all other Schengen countries except Iceland. The Schengen countries are Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain and Sweden, which are EU Member States, as well as Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland, which are non-EU countries.    External border traffic refers to traffic between Finland and non-Schengen third countries. Restrictions have already been lifted earlier for traffic arriving in Finland from the Vatican, and for traffic between Finland and Australia, South Korea, Singapore, Rwanda, Thailand and New Zealand for residents of these countries. Entry from these low-risk countries is not restricted due to the low incidence of COVID-19.    For other countries, the restrictions on entry will be extended until 25 May 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503232418/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/1410869/restrictions-on-entry-into-finland-extended-until-25-may

When internal border control is in place, return traffic, transit traffic or crossing the border are permitted, but for essential reasons only. Internal border traffic refers to traffic between Finland and other countries belonging to the Schengen Area.    Residents of the following countries are allowed to enter Finland on condition that they arrive directly from their country of residence: Australia, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand, New Zealand and Rwanda.    People from other countries not members of the Schengen area are allowed to enter Finland for essential travel only.    The current restrictions on entry into Finland will run to 25 May 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503230938/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/entry-restrictions

The current restrictions on entry into the country will be in effect until 25 May 2021.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517211434/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions

Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084253/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19    ** Recoded as 3G, as  all shops except those deemed essential and a limited list of other services are required to close.

""Only shops selling basic necessities are allowed to open - including bookstores, record stores, DIY, plant and flower stores, hairdressers, shoemakers, chocolatiers, car dealerships, real estate visits - in order to reduce contact in enclosed areas. Businesses that generate large population mixs and thus present a risk of increased circulation of the virus are closed throughout the territory. Thus, are affected by the closure:    - non-food businesses with more than 10,000 square metres of useful commercial space;  - non-food shops in shopping malls and shopping malls with a useful commercial area of more than 10,000 square metres.    To limit the concentration of flows and encourage commercial activity, the possibilities of opening shops on Sundays are widened and establishments are encouraged to take advantage of the opportunities for additional opening on the lunch break. All sectors still subject to administrative closures (bars, restaurants, nightclubs, etc.) or directly affected by sanitary measures will continue to benefit from aid measures."" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210507204759/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Updated guidance encouraging all business to maximise use of telework and minimise infection risk has been published at https://web.archive.org/web/20210507205725/https://www.gouvernement.fr/le-nouveau-protocole-national-en-entreprise-contre-la-covid-19

No policy change. From 6 a.m. to 7 p.m., outings are authorized within a radius of 10 km around your home on presentation of proof of address or travel certificate. Outings should be limited to essential trips (like for grocery shopping) or exercise. Curfew in place from 7 p.m. to 6 a.m.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502134016/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

A nationwide curfew is in place between the hours of 7:00pm and 6:00 am, people are only allowed to leave their homes with a self-issued certificate explaining their need to conduct business trups, travel for medical consultations or vaccinations, compelling family reaons, if they are disabled or aiding a disabled person, travel to stations or airports for the purposes of one of these reasons, or within a 1km radius of their homes for exercising pets.     Restrictions introduced on day-time movements outside the home on 3 April were lifted on 3 May. The government published a timetable for further lifting of restrictions:     May 19, 2021: curfew postponed to 9 p.m. and reopening of shops, terraces, museums, cinemas and theatres with limited gauges;  9 June 2021: curfew at 11pm and indoor cafes and restaurants and gyms reopened; easing telework, in consultation with social partners at the business level;  June 30, 2021: curfew ends.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507204759/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccines available for people aged 55 and older, clinically vulnerable groups and people with comorbidities, key workers, and 'priority professionals' over 55 (teachers, police officers, etc).    Authorized vaccines: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Janssen    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502142817/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

A,B,C:    Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Janssen vaccines are being administered.     For the general public, vaccination against Covid-19 is open to:    - 16-17 year olds with certain serious diseases(a very high-risk, serious condition)with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine;  - adults with disabilities, housed in specialized foster homes or nursing homes;  - people over the age of 18 with a body mass index of more than 30;  - included 18-55 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19 or one or more comorbidities;  - people aged 55 and over regardless of where they live and health (with or without comorbidities);  - adults living in the same household as a severely immunosuppressed person, child or adult (transplanted from solid organs, recent bone marrow transplants, dialysis patients, patients with autoimmune diseases on strong immunosuppressive treatment such as anti-CD20 or anti-metabolites);  - Pregnant women from the second trimester of pregnancy;    From 10 May, vaccinations will be open to anyone over the age of 50. From 12 May, all adults will be able to make an appointment to get vaccinated if vaccine doses are available the day before for the next day.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210507212109/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

A,B,C:    Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Janssen vaccines are being administered.     No change to the groups of people who can be vaccinated announced on 3 May.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210513102023/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

you must use a facemask in all indoor and outdoor public and communal spaces, including work-places and on public transport;  a curfew is in place from 12:30am to 5am;  All hotels, restaurants, cafes, bars are operating as normal, with strict safety protocols in place. Maximum 3 persons permitted to travel in a taxi or a private vehicle (unless all members of the same family).  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524135721/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

In the case of  the movement of workers, the relevant document is required from the Ergani Information System and in case this is not possible, the Employee Traffic Certificate available on the forma.gov.gr. Movements using SMS are allowed (or by filling out the exceptional travel form available on forma.gov.gr or with a handwritten certificate, according to the template available on forma.gov.gr ONLY for the following reasons:    Move for health reasons (i.e. go to a pharmacy, visit the doctor or go to a hospital or health centre, if recommended after contact).  In this case AN SMS with code 1 is sent.  Go to an in-service supply store for essentials where they cannot be sent on time.  In this case the SMS uses code 2.  Go to a public service, if it is not possible to provide electronic or telephone service and only for urgent needs, after setting an appointment for which the citizen is informed in writing or electronically and subject to the additional condition of demonstration of such information. As well as going to the bank, as long as the electronic transaction is not possible.  To switch to a public service or bank, the SMS uses code 3.  Go to help people in need, as well as to transport a spouse or first-degree relative to and from their place of work, if necessary, or escort a student to school by a parent or guardian.  In these cases (i.e. providing assistance, transferring a spouse or relative to work and accompanying a student), SMS with code 4 is sent.  Go to a funeral under the conditions laid down by law or for the transition of divorced parents or parents who are separated necessary to ensure the communication of parents and children, in accordance with the provisions in force.  In these cases the SMS uses code 5.  Physical exercise outdoors or movement with a pet, individually or in two (2) persons, provided that the necessary distance of one and a half (1.5) metres is respected in the latter case. As well as a transition to feed stray animals, if the transition takes place within the municipality of residence of the citizen. In such cases, the SMS uses code 6.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517132536/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map

Greece still has several restrictions. However, the big changes are that residents no longer have to send text messages to a hotline whenever they leave their homes or go shopping, movement is allowed between regions, and a night-time curfew has now been limited to between 00:30 and 05:00.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517131242/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-57113756

https://web.archive.org/web/20210524135721/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.

The Greek government have announced that, from 19 April, arrivals from the UK with proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test, undertaken within the 72 hour period before arrival into Greece are exempted from the need to self-isolate on arrival to Greece. In addition to this they have announced that UK travellers with proof of two COVID-19 vaccinations completed at least 14 days before travel are also exempt from self-isolation (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status). Until there is means to certify vaccinations for international travel, all travellers should continue to obtain a PCR test as stated above.    The exemption from self-isolation detailed above also applies to arrivals from the EU, United States, Serbia, Israel and United Arab Emirates.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517130828/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/entry-requirements#entry-rules-in-response-to-coronavirus-covid-19

https://web.archive.org/web/20210524135721/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus  Anyone travelling to Greece must comply with the Greek authorities’ requirements, including completion of a Passenger Locator Form (PLF) before you travel (both into and out of Greece). Read this section of the travel advice in full and check Greek authorities’ advice to understand how these requirements apply to you.    You must wear a face mask at all times when on an aeroplane, bus, train or ferry travelling to or from Greece; and whilst at airports.    The following measures are in place with respect to travel to Greece:    Travellers must fill in a Passenger Locator Form (PLF) no later than 11.59 PM of the day before arriving in Greece. Please see below for further guidance on the Passenger Locator Form.  Arrivals from the UK must provide either; proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test, undertaken within the 72 hour period before arrival into Greece, or proof of two COVID-19 vaccinations completed at least 14 days before travel (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status). Travellers with proof of either are exempted from the need to self-isolate on arrival to Greece.

Seasonal employees in accommodation and tourist bus services who have been re-hired (mandatory) can be placed on furlough with monthly support for the months of May and June.  Seasonal employees in accommodation and tourist bus services who will not be hired in May and June can be placed on furlough with monthly support through the Ergani system.  Seasonal employees in accommodation and tourist bus services who have been re-engaged can be placed in the Syn-ergasia job retainment scheme starting in July through to September 2021, which offers full coverage of employer insurance contributions for the period of employment.  Seasonal employees who are not eligible for mandatory re-hiring can as of June 1 and for six months from recruitment participate in the labor ministry’s job program which will cover total insurance contributions and subsidize net salary by 200 euros.  Licensed tourist guides and tour leaders will be eligible for special purpose compensation for the months of March, April, and May 2021 after applying to the labor ministry’s Ergani system.  https://archive.ph/ocPZ4

From May 1, shops may be open from 5.30 a.m. until 11 p.m. Shops have to set a limit of one customer per 10 square meters, except in the cases of children under the age of 14, people over the age of 65 and those assisting someone with a disability. Shops will have to ensure that those waiting to be let in can keep a safe distance of 1.5 meters from each other, with the exception of those living in the same household. Customers must also have access to hand sanitation, and shopping carts and trolleys must be disinfected on a regular basis. From April 7, all services may open, such as hairdressing salons, beauty salons, and other services. Restaurants, cafés, and bars can be open between 5 a.m. and 10.30 p.m. Clubs are closed. Factory canteens may be open. Guests need to wear face masks indoors but not outdoors on the terraces. Indoor facilities may be visited only by guests who show their immunity certificates. Restaurant, café, and bar workers need to wear face masks indoors and outdoors. Hotels can only receive guests travelling for business purposes, and tourists who have immunity certificates.  Starting May 1, leisure facilities, including museums, theatres, gyms, swimming pools, cinemas and zoos, will be open for visitors with immunity certificates who can take along underaged family members.    https://archive.vn/8e0IL

As of 15 May terraces of bars and restaurants may open until 9.30 p.m. and the curfew will start at 11 p.m. Shops may reopen between 5:00 a.m. and 9:30 p.m. Hairdressers and cosmeticians may reopen. Public areas and parks remain open.  The Hungarian Police will enforce these restrictions by imposing fines and closing up places that violate the special rules.    https://archive.vn/wx7jU
No policy change. http://web.archive.org/web/20210501114507/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/hirek

All events are banned. Sports matches may only take place in empty stadiums. Outdoor amateur team sports are prohibited. Individual sports activities are permitted. No more than 10 people can attend a family gathering or private event. Minors under 14 are exceptions from this limitation. Funerals can be attended by up to 50 people at a time. At weddings only the witnesses, parents and siblings may attend the ceremony and receptions are banned.    https://archive.vn/8e0IL

As of May 1 curfew starts from 12 a.m. to 5 a.m. everybody is required to stay indoors, whether at home, at a temporary home, or an accommodation.  The only exceptions are for commuting to and from work, and in case of health needs or health emergencies.   General rule is that physical distancing of one and a half meters is to be kept, and face masks – only medical and textile masks that cover the nose and mouth are accepted – are mandatory indoor and outdoor. The regulation applies to everybody, with the exception of children under six. Those who breach the rule will be fined or excluded from travel. In cases of resistance, police can be summoned.    https://archive.vn/8e0IL

As of 15 May terraces of bars and restaurants may open until 9.30 p.m. and the curfew will start at 11 p.m. Shops may reopen between 5:00 a.m. and 9:30 p.m. Hairdressers and cosmeticians may reopen. Public areas and parks remain open.  The Hungarian Police will enforce these restrictions by imposing fines and closing up places that violate the special rules.    https://archive.vn/wx7jU
There are no restrictions on internal movement in Hungary.     https://archive.vn/8e0IL

As a general rule, only Hungarian citizens and their relatives can enter Hungary.  Beginning on September 1, the GOH instituted a COVID-19 entry control scheme, which bans the entry of most foreigners. The decree does not apply to diplomatic or official travel, freight travel, or to anyone who can demonstrate a COVID infection in the last six months.  This restriction is in effect until rescinded by the GOH.  All those entering Hungary are subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine.  Treatment similar to a Hungarian citizen is granted to family members of Hungarians, those with residency status, sports competitors, and cultural event participants.  There are additional exceptions for military convoys, business purposes, cross border workers, sporting events, and for those transiting Hungary along designated corridors.  Additionally, a special exception can be requested through the Hungarian national police.  A 10-day quarantine is currently required for all international arrivals. Travelers may be exempted from such quarantine if they attest with a document containing the results of two SARS-CoV-2 tests (molecular biology examination in compliance with professional medical practice) performed in Hungary at two different times with at least 48 hours between them that the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus was not detected in their body at the time of the tests. However, it is also acceptable if the first of the two tests is performed in one of the Schengen countries, the United States of America or Canada.   Health screening procedures are in place at airports and other ports of entry      https://archive.vn/8e0IL

On April 23, the state-owned development bank MFB launched a HUF 1,490bn package of financial support instruments for companies, consisting of three loan products, two guarantee instruments and four capital programs.  On May 7, the government announced it will purchase up to HUF 150 billion (0.3 percent of GDP) of bonds issued by banks in order to support lending during the crisis and to ensure financial stability. On May 20, the government announced a new wage subsidy program for new hires, with the condition for a company of keeping a worker for at least nine months. Interest-free loans to SMEs will be available from June 12. Half of the program’s budget will be available for investments, while the other 50 percent is intended to finance liquidity and operations. The highest amount available for investments is HUF 150 million, while asset and liquidity financing loans are capped at HUF 300 million. On August 25th, the government announced that it will not be expanding the wage subsidy scheme for all as of end-August, but only for most affected sector till June 2021. Will March 22, wage subsidies and tax relief available to the hospitality sector will be extended to all sectors subject to the new lockdown.   Measures were also taken to provide financial relief to households and corporates borrowers, including: (i) the provision of a grace period of repayment of loans to the Growth Funding Facility (subsidized lending to SMEs supported by the MNB); (ii) the extension of short-term loans to businesses until June 30; (iii) a repayment moratorium on all existing loans, corporate and retail, until the end of this year, with a reprofiling of debt payment thereafter to avoid an increase in monthly payments; and, (iv) a cap on the average annual percentage rate (APR) on new unsecured consumer credit at the central bank base rate (currently, 0.9 percent) plus 5 percent. On September 20, the government extended debt repayment moratorium by six months for select groups.     https://archive.vn/e1v59

Vaccination is voluntary and free of charge. The order in which people are vaccinated is not determined by the order in which they register, but by their vulnerability to disease caused by the coronavirus. Already 16-18-year-olds can take the vaccine, and about 90,000 students studying in technical or vocational schools can take advantage of this opportunity. In the first round, young people who have previously registered and made an appointment will receive the Pfizer vaccine.   Vaccines available in Hungary are the following:  Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Astra Zeneca, Sinopharm, Sputnik V. The Hungarian government has announced that a COVID-19 vaccine will be provided to everyone who is legally present in Hungary and is old enough to receive an approved vaccine.  The vaccine will be provided free of charge.  Residents who are not participants in the Hungarian State Health Insurance program (“TAJ”) will be prioritized after those who are program participants.    Starting on May 4, foreign citizens living in Hungary without TAJ cards can now register for COVID vaccinations here: https://vakcinainfo.gov.hu/.  The registration website is in both English and Hungarian.    https://archive.vn/8e0IL   https://archive.vn/aTqdv   https://archive.vn/0zwq6

1st May 2021, The Irish government has announced a phased relaxation of its strict Covid-19 lockdown over the next six weeks.        May 4  All construction can restart.    Workers who work outdoors (for example: window cleaning, maintenance work) can return to work,      May 10  Inter-county travel    A maximum of 3 households or 6 people from any number of households can visit a private garden.    Outdoor gatherings of 15 people.    Outdoor training of 15 people.    Retail click-and-collect services    Hairdressers, barbers, beauticians reopen by appointment.    Galleries, museums, libraries and other cultural attractions reopen.    Maximum 50 mourners at funeral services. No other events to take place.    Maximum 50 guests at wedding services. Maximum 6 guests at indoor reception or 15 outdoors    Public transport will run at 50 percent capacity    Vaccinated people can meet other households indoors.      From 17 May, all non-essential shops can reopen to customers.      From 2 June, hotels, guest houses and self-catering accommodation will be permitted to trade.    From 7 June, all pubs, regardless of whether they serve food, along with restaurants are set to open up for outdoor services.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210503203945if_/https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/ireland-lockdown-changes-expected-within-24020465    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503204815/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-56935158

From Tuesday 4 May 2021  - All construction work can fully recommence  - Residents in nursing homes where at least 8 out of 10 residents have been fully vaccinated can have 4 routine visits per week. This applies where residents have been fully vaccinated for at least 2 weeks. Residents of all other nursing homes are allowed to have 2 visits per week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507232622/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

From 10 May 2021:    - Hairdressers, barbers and other personal services can reopen by appointment.  - Non-essential shops can offer click and collect services by appointment. Outdoor retail, like gardening centres, can reopen.  - Outdoor training can start for adults in pods of up to 15.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210507232622/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

From 10 May 2021:    - People from 3 households can meet outdoors (including in a garden), or 6 people from any number of households.  - Fully-vaccinated people can meet with one other household (that includes non-vaccinated people) indoors.  - Outdoor training can start for adults in pods of up to 15.  - Church services can be held. On 22nd May, the Minister for Health announced that the designation of the following territories/countries for the purposes of mandatory hotel quarantine would be revoked, effective immediately: Andorra, Georgia, Kuwait, Mongolia, Nigeria and Puerto Rico.    All those intending to travel to Ireland from or via any designated countries/territories,  are required to book accommodation for mandatory hotel quarantine in advance of travel.    The complete list of 50 designated countries/territories is:     Angola, Argentina,  Bahrain, Bangladesh,  Belgium,  Bolivia, Botswana, Brazil, Burundi, Canada, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Costa Rica,  Ecuador, Eswatini, Ethiopia, France, French Guiana, Guyana, India, Kenya,  Lesotho, Luxembourg, Malawi, Maldives, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Paraguay, Panama, Peru, The Philippines, Qatar, Rwanda, Seychelles, Somalia, South Africa, Suriname, Tanzania, Turkey, United Arab Emirates, United States of America, Uruguay, Venezuela, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

The COVID-19 Pandemic Unemployment Payment (PUP) is a social welfare payment for employees and self-employed people who have lost all their employment due to the COVID-19 public health emergency. This has been extended until 30 June 2021.     Employees, self-employed people, workers applying for international protection (including those in direct provision) and students can apply for the COVID-19 Pandemic Unemployment Payment. Both EEA and non-EEA workers qualify.    To qualify for PUP, you must:  Have lost job or been laid off because of COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507233626/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/social_welfare/social_welfare_payments/unemployed_people/covid19_pandemic_unemployment_payment.html

***Recoded from 4G to 3G. While the gov website lists as multiple groups, in reality only three groups - A, B, and C - being vaccinated. Registration for 55 - 69 open, but no vaccines being delivered yet, so doesn't justify a 4G coding. https://web.archive.org/web/20210507232302/https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccine/rollout/    See previous coding note:   A,B,C    The groups currently being vaccinated against COVID-19 are:    - people aged 65 years and older who live in long-term care facilities (group 1)  - frontline healthcare workers (group 2)  - people aged 70 and older (group 3)  - people aged 16 to 69 who are at very high risk (group 4)  - people aged 65 to 69, including those at high risk (group 5 and 6)  - people aged 16 to 64 who are at high risk (group 7)    The COVID-19 vaccines currently approved for use in Ireland are the:    - AstraZeneca vaccine (also known as 'Vaxzevria')  - Moderna vaccine  - Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine (also known as 'Comirnaty')  - Janssen vaccine  - A number of other vaccines are in the final stages of licensing and approval.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507232302/https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccine/rollout/

A,B,C    Groups currently being vaccinated  The groups currently being vaccinated against COVID-19 are:    - people aged 65 years and older who live in long-term care facilities (group 1)  - frontline healthcare workers (group 2)  - people aged 70 and older (group 3)  - people aged 16 to 69 who are at very high risk (group 4)  - people aged 65 to 69, including those at high risk (group 5 and 6)  - people aged 16 to 64 who are at high risk (group 7)  - pregnant women    COVID-19 vaccines being offered  The COVID-19 vaccines currently approved for use in Ireland are the:    - AstraZeneca vaccine (also known as 'Vaxzevria')  - Moderna vaccine  - Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine (also known as 'Comirnaty')  - Janssen vaccine    A number of other vaccines are in the final stages of licensing and approval.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518114057/https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccine/rollout/

The authorities will be authorized to ban unnecessary travel from countries identified as risk zones by the Chief Epidemiologist (14-day notification rate exceeding 1,000 cases per 100,000 population).      Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425145321/https://www.government.is/news/article/2021/04/20/COVID-19-Temporary-introduction-of-stricter-border-measures-/

27 april 2021, A new regulation is issued, banning unnecessary travel from specified high-risk areas due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210509201752/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/iceland-s-response

Note: Only Icelandic citizens and their families, people with permanent residency in Iceland, residents of the EEA/EFTA area,* citizens of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino or Vatican City can travel to Iceland. Others need to apply for exemptions in advance. In all cases, however, travellers must present a negative PCR COVID-19 test, vaccination certificate, or previous infection certificate to be admitted into the country after which they will be monitored.   *Notably, until 31 May 2021, all foreigners who arrive from or have stayed in, for more than 24 hours within the last 14 days, an area where the 14-day incidence rate of infection is higher than 700 persons out of every 100 000 inhabitants, or where sufficient information about the area is not available, are forbidden from entering Iceland. The ban applies to all foreigners, including citizens of the EEA and EFTA, as well as all citizens of third countries.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517171405/https://www.covid.is/categories/travel-to-and-within-iceland  https://web.archive.org/web/20210429185648/https://www.government.is/news/article/2021/04/27/-Ban-on-unnecessary-travel-from-high-risk-areas/

Several measures to combat the economic effect of the COVID-19 pandemic will be instituted or prolonged in the coming days (april 30 2021)  http://web.archive.org/web/20210509205036/https://www.icelandreview.com/politics/government-introduces-hopefully-the-last-economic-measures/

Anticipated economic measures include:   Grant for restoring staff to previous employment ratio – Support for companies to restore employment ratio for staff in reduced employment.  Payments for long-term unemployed – A one-off payment of 100,000 for people experiencing long-term unemployment of 14 months or more  Income-linked unemployment benefits extended – the period of temporary extension of income-linked benefits, from three months to six, will be extended until February 1, 2022  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517180142/https://www.icelandreview.com/politics/government-introduces-hopefully-the-last-economic-measures/

Payment of supportive loans – payment schedule extended for 12 months.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210509205036/https://www.icelandreview.com/politics/government-introduces-hopefully-the-last-economic-measures/

Policy: Masks must be worn wherever the 2-metre social distancing rule cannot be kept between individuals who are not closely linked, with the exception of schools and certain events where guests are seated in booked seats. The obligation to wear a mask does not apply to children born 2005 or later.  Face masks shall be used in public transport, in shops and other services. Face masks shall also be used where it is not possible to ensure a 2-metre distance limit such as in health services, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities. Face masks shall cover the nose and mouth.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517164423/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

Sardinia is the only region being in a Red Zone at the moment.   In red zones distance learning is enforced for 7th grade for primary schools and all remaining primary school levels (7th and 8th) as well as all high school levels must remain closed.  In orange zones in-presence learning for secondary schools (high schools) is guaranteed for 50% up to a max of 75% of the students of a class, the remaining students will have to be on distance-learning.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210430054127/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638

Valle D'Aosta is the only region being classified as a Red Zone.   In red zones distance learning is enforced for 7th grade for primary schools and all remaining primary school levels (7th and 8th) as well as all high school levels must remain closed.  In orange zones in-presence learning for secondary schools (high schools) is guaranteed for 50% up to a max of 75% of the students of a class, the remaining students will have to be on distance-learning.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507054116/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638

All levels are now open in all regions (no region is categorized as a Red Zone). In Orange Zones (Valle d’Aosta, Sicily & Sardinia) for high schools in-presence learning is guaranteed only for 50% to max 75% of students. In Yellow zones high schools guarantee in presence learning for 100% of the students. Still in Yellow Zones masks need to be worn and desks need to be at least 1m apart.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210513163051/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638/

All levels are still open in all regions (as no region is categorized as a Red Zone). In Yellow zones high schools guarantee in presence learning for 100% of the students.   Still in Yellow Zones masks need to be worn and desks need to be at least 1m apart.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210520163129/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638/

More than 80 percent of workers of national companies and government institutions must work from home in Nur-Sultan city. A wide variety of businesses – including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities – are open, in some cases subject to restrictions on hours of operation subject to capacity limitations.   However, some regional and local governments periodically impose restrictions in response to increases in the infection rate.  Ashyq Application:  Businesses that would otherwise be closed or subject to opening and/or occupancy restrictions may open under less restrictive conditions by participating in “Ashyq,” an application that displays a color-coded risk status for each visitor based on information in Ministry of Health COVID-19 infection, PCR test, and vaccination databases.  Individuals wishing to patronize these businesses must have the Ashyq application on a personal device.   https://archive.vn/AicSt

West Kazakhstan established sanitary posts that restrict the movement in and out of the region.   https://archive.vn/v9niR

Checkpoints that control the internal movement are established in some regions. The Deputy prime minister said that the government will not remove the checkpoints in the near future.   Link: https://archive.vn/ITazr

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes, in some cases.  As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk “Red Zones.” An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the “Ashyq” application system (please see further information on “Ashyq” in the Quarantine Information paragraph below).  Kazakhstan’s regions are empowered to take additional measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 as necessary, including erecting checkpoints to limit travel in and out of cities and oblasts.  Before pursuing domestic travel in Kazakhstan, we urge you to research whether checkpoints might be in place that could restrict your ability to travel.   https://archive.vn/AicSt

Has the government of Kazakhstan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Kazakhstan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes, for permanent residents (see below).  Which vaccines are available in Kazakhstan? Sputnik V  On April 7, 2021, the Minister of Health announced in a press briefing that foreigners who live and work in Kazakhstan and have permanent residence cards may receive COVID-19 vaccination free of charge just like Kazakhstani citizens.  https://archive.vn/E8An3

As of May 3, about 1,3 mln people received a vaccine. Currently, there are 3 vaccines available in Kazakhstan on a voluntary basis: Sputnik V, QazVac, and Hayat-Vax.   https://archive.vn/Wfkvr  https://archive.vn/669um
Currently, there are 3 vaccines available in Kazakhstan on a voluntary basis: Sputnik V, QazVac, and Hayat-Vax.   https://archive.vn/2XrTz

COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Kazakhstan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Kazakhstan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes, for permanent residents (see below).  Which vaccines are available in Kazakhstan? Sputnik V, QazVac, and Sinopharm.  On April 7, 2021, the Minister of Health announced in a press briefing that foreigners who live and work in Kazakhstan and have permanent residence cards may receive COVID-19 vaccination free of charge just like Kazakhstani citizens.   https://archive.vn/AicSt

Vaccination. The authorities plan to vaccinate ten million people (over half of the population) free of charge by September 2021, starting with groups with high risk exposure (doctors, teachers, and law enforcement workers).So far, around 1.5 million people have received the first dose, and another 450,000 have been fully vaccinated. The vaccination program relies mostly on locally produced Sputnik V and domestically developed KazVac vaccines. The authorities are also conducting an awareness campaign about vaccination, including a recent show by Minister of Health receiving the locally produced vaccine on TV. https://archive.vn/oo8N6

The second stage will be carried out using vaccines received under the COVAX program for the elderly (aged 60 and over), people with clinical risk factors and the socially vulnerable. The COVAX programme is predicted to reach more than 1.3 million people in the period from June to July 2021. The third stage of vaccinations will continue at the expense of the state and donor organizations for the remaining populations""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210303193606/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/WFP-0000124521-2.pdf  _______________________________________________________________________  Quote: ""According to Kyrgyz Republic authorities Sinopharm is now available at government clinics for all those who wish to receive it. Participation in pre-school and pre-primary education is recommended only for those children whose parents have no possibilities of working from home. Schools in the territories of the municipalities referred to in paragraph 2.1 of Resolution 1226 will follow the model of blended primary education. Schools in the territories of the municipalities that are not listed in this paragraph of the resolution will provide primary education remotely. Vocational education and training and higher education will be provided remotely except initial vocational training combined with a social skills program, mandatory traineeships, practical training or assessment of competencies, which cannot be done remotely.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516140845/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

- Provision of pre-school and pre-primary education. Participation in pre-school and pre-primary education is recommended only for those children whose parents (adoptive parents or guardians) have no possibilities of working from home.  - Schools in the territories of the municipalities referred to in paragraph 2 of the Resolution will follow the model of blended primary education.  - Schools in the territories of the municipalities that are not listed in paragraph 2 of this Resolution will provide primary education remotely or schools selected by administrations of these municipalities will follow the model of blended primary education subject to regular preventive COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) testing of primary school pupils and school staff working in contact with the pupils, or to self-monitoring for COVID-19 (coronavirus infection). Preventive COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) testing or self-monitoring for COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) will not be required in the case of primary school pupils educated outdoors.    - Vocational education and training and higher education will be provided remotely except initial vocational training combined with a social skills programme, mandatory traineeships, practical trainings or assessment of competencies, which cannot be done remotely.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521151237/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Participation in pre-school and pre-primary education is recommended only for those children whose parents (adoptive parents or guardians) have no possibilities of working from home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210526215420/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

From the 22nd of April, outdoor spaces of cafes, bars and restaurants (open 7:00-21:00, with a maximum of 2 customers per table if they are not from the same household) is permitted.   Sightseeing tours up to 10 people are permitted.   Indoor cafes in airports and seaports are allowed to operate.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205239/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/lithuania-enacts-lockdown-exit-plan-7708

From the 26th of April, gyms and sports facilities may open if they provide 20 sq m per person.   Group exercise is permitted (5 people +1 instructor)  Pools and saunas may open, limited to one household use at a time.   Pools may open for school children.     Work from home recommendation is still in place for those who can.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205239/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/lithuania-enacts-lockdown-exit-plan-7708  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205318/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

All stores, outdoor non-food retail stores and marketplaces reopened, providing the required retail space per visitor. Theatres and cinemas may reopen at 30% seating capacity (no standing places), hosting up to 150 spectators.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516140845/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Public catering facilities, restaurants, cafés, bars, nightclubs, other entertainment venues, gambling houses (casinos), amusement arcades, bingo halls, betting and totalisator outlets will be closed except in the case of:    takeaway food or where food can be otherwise delivered to natural and legal persons;  catering provided to the staff of enterprises, establishments or organisations working on shifts, in the territories and/or premises of such enterprises, establishments or organisations;  catering provided in educational, social care, health care, national defence, penitentiary establishments, remand prisons, the Foreigners’ Registration Centre or other establishments, where catering is required by the operational profile of these establishments.  Catering facilities, restaurants, cafés and bars may reopen and operate from 7.00 to 21.00; food and drinks will be consumed while seated at a table outside with up to 2 people at the table except members of one family and/or one household.  Catering facilities, restaurants, cafés and bars may reopen at seaport and airport passenger departure terminals; food and drinks will be consumed while seated at a table with up to 2 people at the table except members of one family and/or one household.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521151237/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

State and municipal institutions and bodies and state and municipal enterprises and the private sector will organise work and provide customer services remotely except where relevant functions (work) have to be performed at the workplace, or relevant functions (work) are performed by  vaccinated or recovered persons, while ensuring conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment. It is obligatory to ensure the performance of the essential and urgent statutory functions (work).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210526215420/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Events will be allowed to host up to 150 spectators, while adhering to the set requirements. Indoor events will only be allowed to take place at maximum 30% seating capacity (no standing places).  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516140845/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Events will be allowed to host up to 150 spectators, while adhering to the set requirements. Indoor events will only be allowed to take place at maximum 30% seating capacity (no standing places), on-line ticketing and/or registration of spectators, mask-wearing by spectators over the age of 6 and other conditions laid down by the State Commander of Emergency Operations.  It will not be allowed to sell food and beverages or to provide other services during these events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521151237/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

indoor events with maximum 150 spectators and/or participants and outdoor events with maximum 300 spectators and/or participants (excluding performers, athletes that participate in high-performance athletic competitions, specialists of high-performance sports and physical activity, instructors of high-performance sports and physical activity, referees, anti-doping officers, organisers and service personnel), organised and held provided organisers of an event can ensure online ticketing and/or registration of spectators and/or participants and control the access of spectators and/or participants to the venue of the event, with spectators and/or participants watching an event seated (except the cases of animal exhibitions), spectators and/or participants over the age of 6 wearing face masks during the entire event    https://web.archive.org/web/20210526215420/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

It will be allowed to hold funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except family and/or household members and persons providing funeral services.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516140845/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Events will be allowed to host up to 150 spectators    It will be allowed to hold funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except family and/or household members and persons providing funeral services.    Religious communities are recommended to hold religious services remotely (except funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except members of the family and/or household or in such a way as to avoid gatherings (while ensuring 10 sq. m. per person and maintaining a distance of at least 2 meters between people or groups of people (up to 2 people or family members); or to refrain from performing religious services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521151237/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

It will be allowed to be in indoor public places in groups of maximum 5 persons or members of two families and/or two households or larger groups, provided this Resolution allows services and activities for larger groups. It will be allowed to be in outdoor public places in groups of maximum 10 persons or members of two families and/or two households or larger groups, provided this Resolution allows services and activities for larger groups.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210526215420/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

There will be restrictions for travelling by regular public transport (city, long-distance and suburban): in long-distance and suburban transport, passengers will be required to travel seated at a distance of at least one meter between each other, as opposed to city transport, where they will be allowed to travel both sitting and standing, provided that a distance of at least one meter is maintained between them.    It will be allowed to travel by vehicles other than regular public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) or vehicles to commute to/from work, or to go to/from points of COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) vaccination, or to go on tours for up to 10 vaccinated or recovered persons, in groups of up to 2 persons or one family and/or one household members. When providing passenger transportation through a ride-hailing and taxi passenger car services, the driver of the vehicle will not be counted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521151237/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

As of Monday, 26 April, tighter self-isolation requirements will apply to arrivals from Seychelles, while arrivals from Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Jordan, Montenegro, Kosovo and Lebanon will continue under the usual self-isolation requirements. Those returning to Lithuania will be required to register with the NPHC no earlier than 48 hours before the start of the trip.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502204408/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/updated-list-of-affected-countries-travellers-will-be-required-to-register-no-earlier-than-48-hours-before-the-start-of-the-trip

The entry of foreigners into the Republic of Lithuania remains restricted, except for residents in the countries of the European Economic Areas, the Swiss Confederation, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Principality of Andora, the Principality of Monaco, the Republic of San Marino and the Holy See (Vatican City State). All persons, arriving to Lithuania from abroad, have to self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations. Even in case of negative test results, self-isolation is mandatory. There are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512051942/https:/lt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/, https://web.archive.org/web/20210418004424/https://urm.lt/default/en/important-covid19

There is a Government Advisory in operation against all non-essential international travel.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210522095944/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/lithuania/    Lithuania currently allows citizens of European Economic Area countries and persons lawfully residing in these countries to enter Lithuania.     The entry of foreigners into the Republic of Lithuania from countries mostly outside the European Union and the European Economic Area (EEA) shall be limited to exceptional cases and those entering Lithuania.     Exceptions for foreign travellers have been laid down in Resolution No 1226 (paragraph 2.1.2).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210522100425/https://www.govilnius.lt/media-news/important-information-regarding-the-coronavirus

Passengers FROM ALL THE COUNTRIES (listed or not listed as affected) travelling on international routes organised and operated by carriers as regular, special and charter services by all modes of transport must complete a QUESTIONNAIRE and present the confirmation of the completed electronic form (QR code) to the carrier before boarding the vehicle.  •    Those arriving in Lithuania from ALL COUNTRIES by their own transport until the moment of crossing the border of the Republic of Lithuania must fill in the QUESTIONNAIRE and provide confirmation of the completed electronic questionnaire (QR code) to NVSC specialists or other officials at the border checkpoint or passenger checkpoint.  People must be tested in the arrival and, despite the result, they must self-isolate per 10 days.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210526220335/https://nvsc.lrv.lt/en/information-on-covid-19/for-arrivals-from-abroad/list-of-countries-affected-by-covid-19-and-requirements-valid-from-24-to-30-may

When an emergency situation or quarantine is declared, remote work is not always possible, so in complicated situations employers may announce downtime or partial downtime, and the State is ready to contribute to the payment of wages to employees.     70 % of the employee’s salary, up to a maximum of EUR 910.5 gross. Obligation to maintain the place of employment for at least 6 months.     90 % of the employee’s salary, up to a maximum of EUR 607 gross. Obligation to maintain the place of employment for at least 3 months.    An allowance of a fixed amount will be paid from the Guarantee Fund to self-employed individuals who have paid social security contributions for at least 3 months during the last year period prior to the declaration of the emergency or quarantine.  The amount of the allowance will be equal to the amount of the current year’s minimum consumption needs, i.e. EUR 257 per month. The allowance will be available from the Employment Service, but it will not be paid to those self-employed individuals who are also employed under an employment contract.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210523174840/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1

When an enterprise declares inactivity due to an emergency or quarantine, the worker shall receive at least the minimum monthly salary and shall not be required to arrive to work. Currently, the minimum monthly salary makes EUR 607 gross or EUR 437 net.    The costs incurred by employers will be reimbursed by the Employment Service in the form of a subsidy to the employer. Subsidies during downtime because of quarantine will be available to companies, non-governmental organisations and associations that employ individuals with disabilities and other supported groups. Only budgetary institutions will not be eligible for subsidies.  70 % of the employee’s salary, up to a maximum of EUR 910.5 gross. Obligation to maintain the place of employment for at least 6 months.    • 90 % of the employee’s salary, up to a maximum of EUR 607 gross. Obligation to maintain the place of employment for at least 3 months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210526220553/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1

To extend the deferral period for payments of residential loans (excluding interest) from 3 to 6 months in the form of a state guarantee for those who have lost their jobs.    • Make it possible to defer the contributions or pay them by installments for electricity and natural gas to UAB Ignitis.    • Recommend that municipalities should offer a possibility to defer public utility payments and payments for heat energy or pay them by installments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210523185029/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-3/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-2/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1

Website specifically about Covid-19 - official source of information by the Government of the Republic of Lithuania on the situation in Lithuania.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524154740/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/

there's a fully informative website provided by Lithuania Government giving organized information about COVID-19 control measures   http://web.archive.org/web/20210526215420/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Testing in Lithuania is divided into targeted testing and preventive testing. As preventive testing is divided into regular (e.g. employees of health care, social care institutions, law enforcement officers and others) and ad-hoc.    From mid-April, rapid antigen tests (LFD), meeting the EU minimum standards (80% sensitivity and 97% specificity) for self-monitoring should be more widely available for sale (57). The European Commission organised the delivery of rapid antigen tests for COVID-19 to the Member States of the European Union, using the Emergency Support Instrument. By 29th April Lithuania has received over 280,000 rapid antigen tests, and expects to receive the remaining 174,000 in the near future.    Population of Lithuania is ~2.8 million - so the number of available tests are low in comparison and priority people will be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210413094046/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

the tests can be provided to symptomatic people or asymptomatic looking for a paid test.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210526221532/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

On 23rd of February 2021  NVSC stated that over the past week its tracers on average reached 90% of people tested positive for COVID-19 within 24 hours to interview them about route of infection and contacts.(17)    From 29th of March 2021, the designated dashboard provides an interactive map of COVID-19 outbreaks (two or more related cases), based on tracing conducted by epidemiologists at the National Center for Public Health: https://nvsc.lrv.lt/lt/naujienos/sukurtas-interaktyvus-covid-19-protrukiu-zemelapis     In mid-April, 87 active outbreaks of coronavirus infection (COVID-19 disease) were recorded in the country's educational institutions – substantially fewer that in the week before (49). Most outbreaks of COVID-19 have been reported in pre-schools settings (20).   according to data collected during epidemiological studies by the National Center for Public Health.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524164229/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Chapter

There are tests available for people in risk of contamination, such as health workers, people living with suspected or confirmed cases, other professionals that have contact with plenty of people   http://web.archive.org/web/20210526221532/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

All persons using public transport must wear a mask. Also, the masks are mandatory at all indoors and outdoors events. Face masks are not required in open spaces, where there are no other people except family members within the radius of 2 meters and in case of exercising individuals, high-performance sports trainings.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512051942/https:/lt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ and https://web.archive.org/web/20210516140845/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

All persons using public transport must wear a mask. Also, the masks are mandatory at all indoors and outdoors events. Face masks are not required in open spaces, where there are no other people except family members within the radius of 2 meters and in case of exercising individuals, high-performance sports trainings.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512051942/https:/lt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ and https://web.archive.org/web/20210516140845/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Face masks are not required in open spaces, where there are no other people except family members within the radius of 2 metres. Face masks are not required also in the following cases:    exercising individuals;  high-performance sports training;  during the provision of a service where a service cannot be provided when a customer is wearing a mask;  persons with disability who cannot wear a mask due to their health condition or where it can adversely affect their health condition. They are recommended to wear a face shield instead.  children over the age of 6 who are educated under pre-school, pre-primary and primary education programmes will not be required to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) while in education establishments and/or their territories.    Face masks are mandatory in common areas of accommodation facilities, also during the allowed contact services. Face masks are required indoors.    It is recommended to wear a face mask at a private party, if held, or when socialising with members of other families /households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524194523/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Residents on the list of priority groups but not yet vaccinated are invited to be vaccinated at any time. Vaccinated or recovered persons will be allowed to visit their loved ones in all the residential social care establishments, foster families, and group and community homes.  There will be no visits to residential social care establishments, foster families, group and community homes, except when visiting residents in terminal condition or when a visit is related to the performance of duties;  social care services will be provided in residential social care establishments and in person’s home in accordance with the conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for public health safety, hygiene and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521151237/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

No policy change. The Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg extended the Covid-19 restrictions in place until May 15, after expiring on April 25th.   Sanitary measures such as mandatory mask-wearing, reduced contact with other student groups, and staggered recreation breaks still apply.     Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070134/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-fr.html     http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780

No policy change. All shops, including non-essential ones, are open to the public with sanitary measures in place. Businesses are still subject to capacity limitations depending on their size. Bill7802 passed by the Chamber of Deputies clarifies that a terrace is ""an outdoor space and in the open air, open on at least three surfaces in order to allow the free circulation of air. and the natural ventilation of the space"".     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426071821/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426072024/https://sante.public.lu/fr/espace-professionnel/recommandations/direction-sante/000-covid-19/recommandations-sanitaires-temporaires/index.html

Bars and restaurants can now open until 10 pm rather than 6 pm. These establishments can now host diners indoors again, though they will have to undergo a rapid test before entering. Up to 4 people can now sit at the same table. Protective measures such as social distance and mask-wearing when not seated still apply.     Links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517100731/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517100958/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/restaurants-bars.html

Bill7802 provides some relaxation for musical and sports activities. Up to 10 people are allowed to come together to practice musical activities if they are seated and respect the two-meter distance between them. For sports, the required area for activity is now 10m2, and sports practice is allowed for groups of +2 people as long as they can keep a cautionary distance of two meters.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426073541/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/sport-religion-culture.html

All indoor and outdoor gatherings are permitted if protective measures are applied. No more than 100 people can participate in these meetings, children included. Masks are still mandatory in all activities open to the public that happen in closed spaces such as shops or supermarkets. There are no policy changes regarding private gatherings, which are restricted to members of the same household or a maximum of 2 visitors, these having to abide by safety measures.     Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074623/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

Up to 150 people are allowed to attend events. Mask-wearing and respecting a minimum distance of 2 meters are mandatory. Gatherings of more than 150 people are only permitted under stricter prevention conditions and with the special dispensation of the health authorities.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517101836/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517100731/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519

No policy change. Wearing a mask is compulsory in public transportation, and some seats are left unoccupied.     Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074740/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

No policy change. There are several protective measures in place when using public transportation. Mask is compulsory, social distance must be respected, and some seats will remain unoccupied.    Links:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210508092939/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

No policy change. All public transportation functions as normal with some protective measures in place.  Social distancing and mask-wearing are mandatory in all public transport.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517102025/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html
No policy change. Curfew from 11 pm to 6 am is still in place countrywide.     Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074847/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html

The nightly curfew has now been pushed from 11 pm to midnight to accommodate the changes in restaurants and bar openings. Thus, a curfew remains in place from midnight to 6 am.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517102352/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html

No policy change. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco, and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 30 June 2021 (inclusive).    Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426075341/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

No policy change. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 30 June 2021 (inclusive).    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508093420/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

Additional sanitary measures apply to travelers coming from India. ""Until 30 June 2021, any person (regardless of nationality and age) who stayed in India during the 14 days prior to his or her arrival on Luxembourg territory must undergo a nucleic acid amplification test of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA - PCR (polymerase chain reaction), TMA (transcription-mediated amplification) or LAMP (loop-mediated isothermal amplification) - upon arrival in the Grand Duchy, and inform the medical analysis laboratory that he or she has stayed in India. This obligation applies to any person who has stayed in India during the 14 days preceding his/her arrival, regardless of the duration of the stay in India and in Luxembourg, and regardless of the means of transport to the Grand Duchy.""    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210516024315/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html
Coordinated public information campaigns are still conducted countrywide.     Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210426081255/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection.html

No policy change.  Weekly updates on governmental mitigation efforts, policy changes, and the evolution of the virus can be found on governmental sources.     Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210517103315/https://covid19.public.lu/en.html

No policy change. Testing is generally available to the population in Luxembourg, especially through the Large Scale Testing (LST) program, which allows the population to get tested without any charge.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426081808/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/get-tested.html

No policy change. Tests are widely available among the population in Luxembourg, especially through the Large Scale Testing (LST). This program was put into place not only to monitor the spread of the virus across the country, but also to allow flexibility and foresight when there is an increase in cases. This allows to break infection chains and to keep the infection rate low. Large Scale Testing allows for residents and cross border workers to get tested either by a PCR test (oral swab) or a serological DBS test (""Dry Blood Spot""). An invitation is sent either via post or e-mail with a personalized code, allowing for everyone to take part free of charge.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508093846/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/get-tested.html

In Luxembourg, vaccine availability is universal. People over 16 years old are eligible to register for the vaccine waiting list, although priority will be given to the oldest people. Residents aged between 30 and 54 have the opportunity to register online to get the Vaxzevria (Astrazeneca) vaccine. According to Prime Minister Xavier Bettel, more than 31.000 people have already registered for this waitlist.     Links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508095540/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210508095738/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519

The Government of Luxembourg and the country's health authorities are leading the vaccination efforts in Luxembourg. According to governmental sources, approximately 7.500 vaccines are injected per day, and more than 277.000 vaccines have already been administered. Luxembourg is now in Phase 6 of its vaccination process. General residents between 16 and 54 years old, starting by the oldest, are being vaccinated.    Links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517104111/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

Four in ten adults in Luxembourg have now had at least one vaccine dose. More than 200.000 people in Luxembourg have had at least one dose of the vaccine. The total number of doses administered totals to more than 304.000    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210521094540/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210520055931/https://www.luxtimes.lu/en/luxembourg/corona-retreats-as-luxembourg-boosts-vaccinations-60a5325ade135b923643eee2
