Teleworking remains compulsory in the private and public sector until May 16th, 2021.   The evening service is extended until 10 p.m. (previously between 7 p.m. and 9:30 p.m.). A traffic exemption for customers providing a certificate by the restaurateur is planned until 10:15 p.m. Home meal delivery is authorized between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m.  Bars may provide service between 6 a.m. and 11 a.m. to residents, employees and hotel guests. Restriction of 6 guests per table with a distance of 1.5 meters between tables.   The one-person footfall for shops is changed to 4 m².  Resumption of indoor sport with a strict health protocol: mask compulsory for practitioners and teachers, hydroalcoholic gel has to be provided, a reservation system needs to regulate the number of athletes.   -	Sports clubs: protocols developed by officials and validated by the Department of Health Action have to be applied  -	Contact or combat sports: only re-athletic training is possible so far  -	Water sports: sailing and solo rowing are authorized  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508152452/https://covid19.mc/en/measures-from-5-3-21/

On April 30th, the previous national state of emergency was declared unconstitutional and has been lifted. This state of emergency was meant to last from 1 April until 30 May 2021. This included a curfew between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. in Chisinau and Balti cities, and banning people’s presence in parks, forests, playgrounds, and sport or leisure areas in these cities. Curfews are no longer in place in Chisinau and Balti. In designated ""red code"" areas where infection rates are high, individuals are allowed to leave their homes only for essential purposes.     The National Public Health Commission also convened a meeting. CNESP members have mandated the territorial commissions to take the decision to establish a state of emergency in public health at local level in case the incidence of cases exceeds 100 infections per 100 thousand citizens.    Under existing directives, public institutions and private businesses are limited to operating with no more than 30 percent of their staff working on-site, with the remainder working remotely. Most businesses in Moldova are permitted to operate provided they adhere to strict health and safety measures, though all public offices close at 16:00 daily, and bars and restaurants must close from 20:00-07:00. Markets are permitted to operate between the hours of 07:00-15:00; shopping malls must close by 18:00. Concert halls and nightclubs remain closed until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504062617/https://www.moldova.org/en/there-will-be-snap-elections-constitutional-court-cancelled-the-state-of-emergency-the-president-announced-a-ballot-date/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143119/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/01/21002456  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405150436/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/02/21002488  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405144922/https://www.moldova.org/en/state-of-emergency-in-moldova-controlling-coronavirus-infections-or-parliaments-dissolution/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142342/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Moldova's international entry restrictions remain largely unchanged by comparison with those that started in force April 3rd. All persons in possession of a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 72 hours before boarding, as well as those who can provide proof of being vaccinated for COVID-19, may enter the country without restrictions. All travelers must complete an epidemiological form. All arrivals who do not possess a PCR test result or proof of vaccine must self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival. Persons in transit, freight transporters, persons traveling for health or humanitarian reasons, persons traveling for business purposes proven by an invitation from or contract with a citizen/resident of Moldova, as well as cross border workers are exempt from self-isolation. Travelers may exit self-isolation by testing negative on a COVID-19 PCR test after the tenth day of isolation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17

""Childcare and education  Daycare centres for children aged under 4 are open.  Primary schools are open.   Out-of-school care is open.  Secondary schools are open. Higher professional education institutions (HBO) and universities are partially open. They are still mainly offering remote and online learning. Each student can attend in-person classes approximately onde day per week.   Pupils and students can attend their school, institution or university in person for practical training, tests and exams.  Vulnerable pupils and students can also be offered support on site at their school, institution or university. ""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515114846/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/coronavirus-measures-in-brief

""Outdoor seating areas at restaurants and cafés to partially reopen  Outdoor seating areas at restaurants and cafés may be open from 12:00 to 18:00, under certain conditions. Each establishment may have a maximum of 50 guests. Each guest must be assigned a seat. Self-service is not allowed. No more than 2 people may be seated at a table, sitting 1.5 metres apart. However, this limit does not apply if everyone at the table is part of the same household or if the party includes children under 13. Visitors can go indoors only to pay, use the cloakroom or go to the toilet. Face masks must be worn indoors.     These conditions will be relaxed further in the next steps of the reopening plan.     Shops and markets to reopen  All shops may admit customers without an appointment. Certain conditions still apply, such as a limit on the number of shoppers allowed inside at the same time. It’s still important to avoid busy places, so go to the shops at quiet times, such as early in the morning. And go alone if possible. Shops selling non-essential goods, such as clothes shops, can be open between 6:00 and 20:00. Supermarkets and other shops selling essential goods may operate in accordance with their usual opening hours. Wearing a face mask in shops is still compulsory.    Non-food articles, like clothing and cosmetics, may again be sold at general markets.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210430111400/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2021/04/20/step-1-shops-and-outdoor-seating-at-restaurants-and-cafes-will-partially-reopen-evening-curfew-lifted

""Authorities have postponed the next stage of the easing of COVID-19 restrictions as of May 5 as a result of high hospital admission rates; museums gyms, and other cultural and leisure facilities were due to reopen May 11, though will now remain closed until at least May 18. Nonessential shops are operating 06:00-22:00 subject to hygiene and social distancing requirements and catering establishments are permitted to provide outdoor services 12:00-18:00. Additionally, households can host up to two guests and visit one other home per day. Many nonessential facilities remain closed. Individuals must work from home where possible. Persons aged 13 and over must wear protective face coverings in indoor public areas and on public transport.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515113015/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475136/netherlands-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-may-5-update-36

""Domestic RestrictionsAuthorities also plan to ease certain domestic restrictions. Starting May 19, indoor sports facilities, as well as outdoor leisure facilities such as nature parks and zoos, will be allowed to reopen. Moreover, catering establishments will be allowed to operate their outdoor dining spaces between the hours of 06:00-20:00 rather than the current restricted hours of 12:00-18:00.    Under existing directives, nonessential shops may operate 06:00-22:00 subject to hygiene and social distancing requirements. Additionally, households can host up to two guests and visit one other home per day. Some nonessential facilities remain closed. Individuals must work from home where possible. Persons aged 13 and over must wear protective face coverings in indoor public areas and on public transport.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521164549/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/477996/netherlands-authorities-plan-to-ease-covid-19-restrictions-from-may-15-update-37

""International Travel RestrictionsAuthorities are also maintaining international entry restrictions as of May 5. Entry is generally only permitted for residents of EEA or Schengen-associated countries, as well as those of the Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand. Officials prohibit most travel from other countries. Exemptions are in place for healthcare workers, people traveling to seek medical attention, persons traveling for urgent family reasons, staff traveling to or from British or Dutch drilling platforms, air or sea crews traveling in the performance of their work, transiting EEA or Schengen Area residents, and returning Dutch nationals and residents.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515113015/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475136/netherlands-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-may-5-update-36

""Authorities in the Netherlands plan to ease the nation's COVID-19 restrictions on international travel and domestic activities. Effective May 15, the government will lift its existing recommendation against travel to foreign countries with low infection rates. Moreover, individuals arriving from designated low-risk destinations may enter the Netherlands without restrictions. As of May 12, authorities classify Australia, China, Finland, Greece (the North Aegean region), Iceland, New Zealand, Portugal, Rwanda, Saba, Singapore, Sint Eustatius, Sint Maarten, South Korea, Spain (the Balearic Islands), and Thailand as low-risk countries and territories.    All other permitted travelers must possess either a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 24 hours prior to boarding transport, or a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in the Netherlands coupled with a negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to boarding. Authorities will not accept results from self-administered tests. Transit passengers are also subject to this requirement. All arrivals must also self-isolate for 10 days on arrival; this can be shortened by taking a COVID-19 test on or after day five of the self-isolation period. Additional exceptions are possible for individuals with an essential function or need, such as cross-border workers, health workers, on-duty security forces, freight workers, and diplomats. All travelers arriving via air must fill out a declaration form prior to entry.    Entry is generally only permitted for residents of EEA or Schengen-associated countries, as well as those of the Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand. Officials prohibit most travel from other countries. Exemptions are in place for healthcare workers, people traveling to seek medical attention, persons traveling for urgent family reasons, staff traveling to or from British or Dutch drilling platforms, air or sea crews traveling in the performance of their work, transiting EEA or Schengen Area residents, and returning Dutch nationals and residents.  Authorities have suspended flights from India, South Africa, Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay, and Venezuela until at least May 15 due to concerns regarding active COVID-19 variants. The suspension does not apply to cargo flights.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521164549/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/477996/netherlands-authorities-plan-to-ease-covid-19-restrictions-from-may-15-update-37

Schools in Level B zones require closure for higher education: ""The premises should be closed to all students at universities, colleges and vocational colleges. All teaching should be offered digitally."" Coded as 2T to reflect that there are currently zones at Level B. http://web.archive.org/web/20210508115341/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/strong-measures-in-municipalities-in-norway/

""Authorities in Oslo plan to ease certain COVID-19-related restrictions effective May 6. Non-essential stores and shopping malls will be allowed to reopen in the Norwegian capital. Moreover, schools and daycares will be allowed to increase their operating capacities. Still, other restrictions will remain in force in the cities, with gatherings continuing to be restricted to 10 people and catering establishments only being allowed to offer carryout services. The use of protective facemasks remains mandatory where social distancing of 2 meters (6 feet) cannot be observed.    Nationwide outside of Oslo, nonessential businesses and services may operate, albeit subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures. Individuals are advised to limit their social contact and avoid all nonessential travel; employees must work from home wherever possible. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Municipalities with higher rates of infection may impose stricter measures within their jurisdictions. Persons may receive up to five guests in private homes. Up to 100 people are allowed at indoor events with assigned seating, while up to 200 people can attend outdoor events with assigned seating. Indoor events without assigned seating are capped at 10 attendees, while such events outdoors are capped at 50 people.""      https://web.archive.org/web/20210515110930/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475281/norway-authorities-to-ease-certain-covid-19-restrictions-in-oslo-from-may-6-update-42

Schools are opening at different levels on different dates. However, adult education is still closed    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521160601/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/barnehager-og-skoler/

""International Entry RestrictionsUnder existing directives, only Norwegian citizens and legal residents are allowed to enter the country; however, exemptions are in place for close family members of Norwegian residents, transport workers, individuals in transit, and foreigners who work in critical fields. All travelers, including Norwegian citizens and residents, need to provide a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to arrival; persons arriving by plane may take the test no more than 24 hours before the scheduled departure time for the first leg of the flight. Upon arrival, travelers must take a rapid coronavirus test at the airport or border and wait at the test station until the result is known.    Authorities require all persons returning from nonessential travel abroad, including Norwegian nationals and permanent residents, as well as all travelers from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Iraq, including those returning from essential trips, to quarantine at designated hotels for 10 days. The quarantine period may be shortened if a negative COVID-19 test result is received no earlier than seven days after entry into the country. There are a limited number of exceptions under which arrivals are not required to quarantine. In addition, business travelers who are able to document that their employer can provide suitable alternative accommodations may be exempt from the hotel quarantine.    All permitted travelers from high-risk areas must register with authorities within 72 hours before arrival. As of May 5, only Greenland, the Faroe Islands, and the Finnish hospital districts of Central Ostrobothnia, Lappi, North Karelia, and Ita-Savo are not considered high-risk areas. Cross-border commuters from Sweden and Finland are permitted to enter Norway without the need to isolate provided they take a COVID-19 test every seven days.""      https://web.archive.org/web/20210515110930/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475281/norway-authorities-to-ease-certain-covid-19-restrictions-in-oslo-from-may-6-update-42

Up to 100 people are allowed at indoor events with assigned seating, while up to 200 people can attend outdoor events with assigned seating. Indoor events without assigned seating are capped at 10 attendees, while such events outdoors are capped at 50 people.""      https://web.archive.org/web/20210515110930/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475281/norway-authorities-to-ease-certain-covid-19-restrictions-in-oslo-from-may-6-update-42

Face masks are required by those in quarantine travelling in public spaces. They are also required in Oslo, however it seems that they are only recommended nationally.   ""Authorities in Oslo plan to ease certain COVID-19-related restrictions effective May 6. Non-essential stores and shopping malls will be allowed to reopen in the Norwegian capital. Moreover, schools and daycares will be allowed to increase their operating capacities. Still, other restrictions will remain in force in the cities, with gatherings continuing to be restricted to 10 people and catering establishments only being allowed to offer carryout services. The use of protective facemasks remains mandatory where social distancing of 2 meters (6 feet) cannot be observed.    Nationwide outside of Oslo, nonessential businesses and services may operate, albeit subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures. Individuals are advised to limit their social contact and avoid all nonessential travel; employees must work from home wherever possible. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Municipalities with higher rates of infection may impose stricter measures within their jurisdictions. Persons may receive up to five guests in private homes. Up to 100 people are allowed at indoor events with assigned seating, while up to 200 people can attend outdoor events with assigned seating. Indoor events without assigned seating are capped at 10 attendees, while such events outdoors are capped at 50 people.""      https://web.archive.org/web/20210515110930/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475281/norway-authorities-to-ease-certain-covid-19-restrictions-in-oslo-from-may-6-update-42

The final phase of easing of lockdown for the majority of Portugal was antecipated 2 days and will now come in to force on Saturday, May 1, with much of the country returning to relative normality.     The advance in the easing of lockdown “applies to most of the continent's territory, it applies to 270 of the 278 counties on mainland Portugal"", said António Costa.     Restrictions in place for each of the phases:    First phase of the plan  The restrictions and measures foreseen in the first phase of the easing of lockdown plan will again be applied, starting on Saturday, in Portimão and in the parishes of São Teotónio and Almograve, in the municipality of Odemira.    - The setback implies the closure of terraces, shops up to 200 square meters (m2) with a door to the street, gyms, museums, monuments, palaces, art galleries and the like.  - There is a ban on fairs and non-food markets, as well as low-risk sports.    What is allowed?  - Trade at the door for takeaway;  - Hairdressing salons, manicures and similar, with prior appointment;  - Retail establishments for books and musical supports;  - Parks, gardens, green spaces and leisure spaces;  - Libraries and archives.    Second phase of the plan    The second phase of easing of lockdown applies to the municipalities of Aljezur, Resende and Carregal do Sal.    What is allowed?  - Operation of stores up to 200 m2 with a door to the street;  - Fairs and non-food markets (by municipal decision);  - Operation of terraces, with a maximum limitation of four people per table, until 10:30 pm on weekdays and until 1:00 pm on weekends;  - Practice of sports modalities considered to be of low risk;  - Outdoor physical activity for up to four people;  - Operation of gyms without group classes;  - Functioning of social facilities in the area of ??disability.    Third phase of the plan  Miranda do Douro, Paredes and Valongo are the municipalities that remain in the third phase of the easing of lockdown.    What is allowed?    - Opening of all stores and shopping centres;  - Opening of restaurants, cafes and pasty shops (with a maximum of four people per table inside or 6 per table on terraces), until 22:30 on weekdays or 13:00 on weekends and holidays;  - Cinemas, theatres, auditoriums;  - Citizen stores with face-to-face service by appointment.  - Medium risk sports modalities;    Fourth phase of the plan    The fourth and final phase of the easing of lockdown will be applied to most of mainland Portugal, precisely 270 of the 278 municipalities.    What is allowed?    - Restaurants, cafes and pastries can operate, either during the week or on weekends, until 10:30 pm, with the limitation limited to a maximum of six people per table inside and 10 people per table on the terraces;  - Commerce in general can be open until 21:00 on weekdays and until 19:00 on weekends and holidays;  - Cultural shows start at 10:30 pm as the cut-off time;  - Practice of all sports is now allowed, as well as and for all outdoor physical activity;  - Gyms can work with group classes, observing the rules of safety and hygiene;    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173312/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-04-30/portugal-moving-into-final-phase-of-lockdown/59652    In the entire mainland, bars and clubs remain close and there is no expected date for the reopening.    Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669    Remote working is still mandatory, when possible, until May 16.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130182809/https://www.timeout.pt/lisboa/pt/coisas-para-fazer/o-estado-de-calamidade-foi-decretado-quais-sao-as-regras    Note: Since bars and clubs remain close, in mainland Portugal, the code remains unchanged.

The government announced that the restrictions in the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve, in Odemira, will continue at least until next Thursday (day of the weekly evaluation).  In these two parishes terraces, larger stores, gymnasiums, museums, monuments and similar establishments, and the prohibition of fairs and non-food markets, as well as low-risk sports, remains in place. Establishments that allowed to remain open include beauty salons, manicures and with appointment, book and music stores, libraries, parks, gardens, green spaces and leisure spaces.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507233028/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/governo-decide-manter-cerca-sanitaria-em-duas-freguesias-de-odemira--13693276.html  Note: In the entire mainland, bars and clubs remain close and there is no expected date for the reopening hence the 2G code (http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669).

""Restrictions implemented on 5 April, but maintained from 14 to 30 May in the municipalities of Resende and Odemira (São Teotónio parish)  - Opening of museums, monuments, palaces, art galleries and similar;  - Opening of shops up to 200 m2 with a door to the street;  - Non-food fairs and markets allowed upon municipal decision;  - Opening of terraces (groups of maximum 4 people allowed);  (...)   - Opening of swimming pools;  - Opening of golf courses.    Restrictions implemented on 19 April, but maintained from 14 to 30 May in the municipalities of Arganil and Lamego  - Opening of cinemas, theatres, auditoriums, concert halls;  - Opening of all shops and shopping centres until 9 pm on working days and until 1 pm on weekends and public holidays;  - Opening of restaurants, cafes, and bakeries until 10:30 pm on working days and until 1 pm on weekends and public holidays. Groups of 4 people are allowed inside or 6 people on terraces    (...) Measures implemented on May 1  - Opening of restaurants, cafés, and pastry shops until 10.30 p.m. Groups of 6 people are allowed inside or 10 people on terraces.    (...) From May 13:  - Fun fairs;  - Private amusement parks;  - Water parks.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514214629/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Teleworking will be mandatory, whenever the situation allows, until the end of May. This does not require any agreement between the employer and employees.To reinforce this rule, ""all workers who have to travel for work in person [either on weekdays or at the weekend] need a credential provided by the employer"".  In addition, there is no expected date for the reopening of bars and clubs.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514220806/https://www.timeout.pt/lisboa/pt/coisas-para-fazer/o-estado-de-calamidade-foi-decretado-quais-sao-as-regras    Note: Code remains unchanged since no announcement was made with regards the reopening of bars and clubs that remain closed in the entire mainland.

The Minister of State and the Presidency announced this Thursday that the municipality of Resende will move forward in the process of deconfinement. In the opposite direction, in Montalegre and Odemira the measures enacted on April 19 will apply. In addition, Arganil and Lamego are again subject to the same restrictions, since the indicators on the incidence of covid-19 per 100 thousand inhabitants do not show significant improvements. In these municipalities, all shops and shopping centers, restaurants, cafes and pastry shops are open (with a maximum of four people per table inside or six by table on terraces) until 22:30 on weekdays or 13:00 on weekends and holidays. Cinemas, theaters, auditoriums, concert halls, Lojas do Cidadão with in-person service are also open.     With the exception of the four counties that are now in the third phase of deconfinement, the remaining 274 municipalities, including those on alert, remain in the fourth phase of the deconfinment plan. In this phase, restaurants and shows are allowed to operate/take place until 10:30 pm, shops in general until 9:00 pm on weekdays and until 7:00 pm on weekends and holidays. Restaurants, cafes and pastry shops can operate but tables are allowed to have a maximum of six people per table inside and ten people per table on the terraces. All sports can be practiced, as well as all physical activity outdoors. The capacity for weddings and baptisms is limited to 50% of the venue capacity. Amusement parks, children's playgrounds, other than public ones, and water parks may operate in these municipalities.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522212150/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/20-05-2021/covid-19-resende-avanca-no-desconfinamento-montalegre-e-odemira-recuam    Note: Bars, nightclubs, casinos and similar establishments remain closed in the entire mainland - hence the 2G code (http://web.archive.org/web/20210522162828/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/situacao-de-calamidade/).

The final phase of easing of lockdown for the majority of Portugal will start on Saturday, May 1, with much of the country returning to relative normality.   The advance in the easing of lockdown “applies to most of the continent's territory, it applies to 270 of the 278 counties on mainland Portugal"", said António Costa.     Restrictions in place for each of the phases:    - First phase of the plan  The restrictions and measures foreseen in the first phase of the easing of lockdown plan will again be applied, starting on Saturday, in Portimão and in the parishes of São Teotónio and Almograve, in the municipality of Odemira.  Outdoor and indoor events are prohibited. There is also a ban on fairs and non-food markets.     - Second phase of the plan  The second phase of easing of lockdown applies to the municipalities of Aljezur, Resende and Carregal do Sal.  The decision to allow or not fairs and non-food markets depends on each municipality. Outdoor and indoor events are not allowed.  Operation of terraces, with a maximum limitation of four people per table, is only allowed until 10:30 pm on weekdays and until 1:00 pm on weekends and outdoor physical activity cannot exceed four participants.    - Third phase of the plan  Miranda do Douro, Paredes and Valongo are the municipalities that remain in the third phase of the easing of lockdown.  Outdoor events with reduced capacity (five people per 100 m²) are now allowed.   Restaurants, cafes and pasty shops can allow a maximum of four people per table inside or 6 per table on terraces and outdoor physical activity is allowed for groups of up to 4 people.    - Fourth phase of the plan  The fourth and final phase of the easing of lockdown will be applied to most of mainland Portugal, precisely 270 of the 278 municipalities.  No measures were announced with regards to public events (rules are the same as in the third phase) - Outdoor events with reduced capacity (five people per 100 m². In restaurants, cafes and pastries groups are limited to a maximum of six people per table inside and 10 people per table on the terraces.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173312/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-04-30/portugal-moving-into-final-phase-of-lockdown/59652    In addition to the restrictions presented above, in the entire continental territory:    - Football matches will not allow public.   - Festivals are still prohibited. However, the health authorities have started to promote pilot-events to test and understand if large public events will be allowed in the coming months.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669    On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.     The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Circulation in the public road is not allowed, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República. These exceptions include: sale and acquisition of essential goods and services in establishments that are open in these parishes; travel to and from work; for health-related reasons; support provision to the elderly, children, dependents and vulnerable individuals.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2    NOTE: Considered to be a general restriction since larger events such football matches and festivals are not allowed in the entire mainland.

Restrictions implemented on 5 April, but maintained from 14 to 30 May in the municipalities of Resende and Odemira (São Teotónio parish)  No events are allowed.     Restrictions implemented on 19 April, but maintained from 14 to 30 May in the municipalities of Arganil and Lamego  Outdoor events allowed with reduced attendance.    Measures implemented on May 1  Large outdoor and indoor events allowed with reduced occupancy.    From May 13:  - Fun fairs;  - Private amusement parks;  - Water parks.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514214629/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    ""In addition to the restrictions presented above, in the entire continental territory:    - Football matches will not allow public.   - Festivals are still prohibited. However, the health authorities have started to promote pilot-events to test and understand if large public events will be allowed in the coming months.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669    NOTE: Considered to be a general restriction since larger events such football matches and festivals are not allowed at this point in the entire mainland.

Sporting won the Portuguese league tonight and before and after the game thousands of supporters gathered around the stadium to watch the game and celebrate the victory despite the law/restriction that limits public gatherings to 10 people.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514224520/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/a-festa-que-quebrou-todas-as-regras-sem-se-ouvir-uma-palavra-a-cabrita-13710603.html

""The Champions League final will now be staged in Porto in Portugal after the UK government and UEFA could not reach agreement over quarantine exemptions  (...) The all-English final between Manchester City and Chelsea was originally scheduled for the Ataturk Stadium in Istanbul on May 29, but the switch will be confirmed by UEFA on Thursday.  (...) the 50,000-capacity Estadio do Dragao in Porto has now been lined up as the venue for the final after UEFA struck a deal with the Portuguese authorities over the attendance at the match. Chelsea and Manchester City will each receive a ticket allocation of between 4,500 and 6,000.  But health experts and MPs have criticised the decision for putting supporters at unnecessary risk in the middle of a pandemic, insisting UEFA should have foregone VIPs this year and made it a 'fans' final' in London.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514223553/https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/sportsnews/article-9565593/Champions-League-final-goes-Portugal-ministers-refused-waive-covid-quarantine-VIPs.html

Portugal is currently under a state of calamity. Public gatherings (outside) are limited to 10 people, except if individuals belong to the same household, in all municipalities.    In the municipalities (274) who are currently in the 4th phase of the deconfinement plan (see C2 for additional information and the list) certain events, if these follow the guidelines of the Directorate-General for Health, are allowed:    - religious ceremonies, including community celebrations  - family events, including weddings, baptisms up to 50% of the venue capacity  - corporate events held in venues suitable for this purpose, namely conference rooms, tourist establishments, venues suitable for holding trade fairs and outdoor spaces, with reduced capacity  - other indoor or outdoor events, with reduced capacity.    Funerals are allowed but measures that prevent large agglomerations of people and guarantee social distancing guidelines, namely the establishment of a maximum attendance limit, determined by local authorities, must be implemented.    In restaurants gatherings are limited to 6 people indoor 10 people on open terraces.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522162828/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/situacao-de-calamidade/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210522212150/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/20-05-2021/covid-19-resende-avanca-no-desconfinamento-montalegre-e-odemira-recuam    In the municipalities currently in the 3rd phase (4) the following rules apply:  - Restaurants, cafes, and bakeries can open but groups are limited to 4 and 6 people indoor and on restaurant terraces;   - Physical activity and outdoor training up to 6 people;  - Outdoor events allowed with reduced attendance.    Nautical events and exhibitions, aeronautical tests and exhibitions, parades, popular celebrations, folkloric manifestations or similar ones are still prohibited.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522161631/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    In addition to the restrictions presented above, in the entire continental territory:    - Football matches will not allow public.   - Festivals are still prohibited. However, the health authorities have started to promote pilot-events to test and understand if large public events will be allowed in the coming months.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669    Note: Code remains unchanged since the majority large public events such as festivals, football matches, manifestations and other outdoor events are still not allowed and public gatherings (outside) are limited to 10 people

The final phase of easing of lockdown for the majority of Portugal will start on Saturday, May 1, with much of the country returning to relative normality.   The advance in the easing of lockdown “applies to most of the continent's territory, it applies to 270 of the 278 counties on mainland Portugal"", said António Costa.     Restrictions in place for each of the phases:    - First phase of the plan (see below for additional information)  The restrictions and measures foreseen in the first phase of the easing of lockdown plan will again be applied, starting on Saturday, in Portimão and in the parishes of São Teotónio and Almograve, in the municipality of Odemira.  The setback implies the closure of terraces, shops up to 200 square meters (m2) with a door to the street, gyms, museums, monuments, palaces, art galleries and similar establishments.    - Second phase of the plan  The second phase of easing of lockdown applies to the municipalities of Aljezur, Resende and Carregal do Sal.  Operation of terraces, with a maximum limitation of four people per table, until 10:30 pm on weekdays and until 1:00 pm on weekends;  Outdoor physical activity for up to four people  Operation of gyms without group classes;    - Third phase of the plan  Miranda do Douro, Paredes and Valongo are the municipalities that remain in the third phase of the easing of lockdown.  Outdoor events with reduced capacity (five people per 100 m²) are now allowed.   Restaurants, cafes and pastries can operate with the occupation limited to four people per table inside or 6 per table on terraces).  Outdoor physical activity for up to 6 people.  Weddings and baptisms with a 25% capacity.    - Fourth phase of the plan  The fourth and final phase of the easing of lockdown will be applied to most of mainland Portugal, precisely 270 of the 278 municipalities.  Restaurants, cafes and pastries can operate with the occupation limited to a maximum of six people per table inside and 10 people per table on the terraces;    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173312/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-04-30/portugal-moving-into-final-phase-of-lockdown/59652    On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.     The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Circulation in the public road is not allowed, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República. These exceptions include: sale and acquisition of essential goods and services in establishments that are open in these parishes; travel to and from work; for health-related reasons; support provision to the elderly, children, dependents and vulnerable individuals.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2

Restrictions implemented on 19 April, but maintained from 14 to 30 May in the municipalities of Arganil and Lamego  (...) restaurants, cafes, and bakeries (...) Groups of 4 people are allowed inside or 6 people on terraces;  - Physical activity and outdoor training up to 6 people;  - Outdoor events allowed with reduced attendance.    (...) Groups of 6 people are allowed inside or 10 people on terraces;  - Large outdoor and indoor events allowed with reduced occupancy.    From May 13:  - Fun fairs;  - Private amusement parks;  - Water parks."" However, the health authorities have started to promote pilot-events to test and understand if large public events will be allowed in the coming months."" Portugal is currently under a state of calamity. Public gatherings (outside) are limited to 10 people, except if individuals belong to the same household, in all municipalities.    In the municipalities (274) who are currently in the 4th phase of the deconfinement plan (see C2 for additional information and the list) certain events, if these follow the guidelines of the Directorate-General for Health, are allowed:    - religious ceremonies, including community celebrations  - family events, including weddings, baptisms up to 50% of the venue capacity  - corporate events held in venues suitable for this purpose, namely conference rooms, tourist establishments, venues suitable for holding trade fairs and outdoor spaces, with reduced capacity  - other indoor or outdoor events, with reduced capacity.    Funerals are allowed but measures that prevent large agglomerations of people and guarantee social distancing guidelines, namely the establishment of a maximum attendance limit, determined by local authorities, must be implemented.    In restaurants gatherings are limited to 6 people indoor 10 people on open terraces.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522162828/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/situacao-de-calamidade/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210522212150/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/20-05-2021/covid-19-resende-avanca-no-desconfinamento-montalegre-e-odemira-recuam    In the municipalities currently in the 3rd phase (4) the following rules apply:  - Restaurants, cafes, and bakeries can open but groups are limited to 4 and 6 people indoor and on restaurant terraces;   - Physical activity and outdoor training up to 6 people;  - Outdoor events allowed with reduced attendance.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522161631/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Note: Code remains unchanged since in restaurants groups are limited to 6 and in terraces to 10 people, and public gatherings (outside) are limited to 10 in ALL municipalities.

In taxis / TVDE, the front seats must be used only by the driver, and passenger occupancy cannot exceed 2/3 of the remaining space."" On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.   The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Circulation in the public road is not allowed, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República. These exceptions include: sale and acquisition of essential goods and services in establishments that are open in these parishes; travel to and from work; for health-related reasons; support provision to the elderly, children, dependents and vulnerable individuals.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2

The government announced that the restrictions in the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve, in Odemira, will continue at least until next Thursday (day of the weekly evaluation). No changes in the stay at home requirements (listed in the previous note) have been announced.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507233028/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/governo-decide-manter-cerca-sanitaria-em-duas-freguesias-de-odemira--13693276.html http://web.archive.org/web/20210511001135/https://www.cm-odemira.pt/pages/536?news_id=2126

The President of the Portuguese Republic, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, announced that the sanitary fence in Odemira will be lifted immediately.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514225530/https://tvi24.iol.pt/politica/11-05-2021/marcelo-anuncia-fim-da-cerca-sanitaria-em-odemira-hoje-mesmo    At this stage the general principle is to stay at home whenever possible, but it is an individual decision, that is recommended by the Government.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514220806/https://www.timeout.pt/lisboa/pt/coisas-para-fazer/o-estado-de-calamidade-foi-decretado-quais-sao-as-regras

On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.   The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Road traffic to and from these two parishes in a sanitary fence in the municipality of Odemira is forbidden, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2

However, due to the reduction of the incidence rates, certain modifications have been made: those who need to enter these two parishes for example for work-related reasons, testing, residence identification, will be allowed to enter. The President of the Portuguese Republic, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, announced that the sanitary fence in Odemira will be lifted immediately. ""Most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from May 1 and the land border with Spain will reopen for normal travel after a three-month hiatus.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/    ""Citizens coming from Brazil, Cyprus, Croatia, France, India, Lithuania, Netherlands, South Africa and Sweden entering Portugal by land must comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities.""    (...)Flights to and from Portugal are allowed for:  - Flights to and from the countries of the European Union or from Schengen Associated countries  - (...) Flights to and from other countries (which are not members of the European Union or which are not countries associated with the Schengen Area) for ""essential travel"" only;  - Flights intended to allow the return to Portugal of nationals or foreign citizens holding a residence permit in Portugal and flights intended to allow the return to their countries of foreign citizens who are in Portugal, provided that they are promoted by the competent authorities of those countries.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501190749/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

""Portugal is to resume admitting tourists from most European countries on Monday, the interior ministry said, following months of restrictions to prevent the spread of Covid-19.  Travellers from European Union countries with coronavirus rates below 500 cases per 100,000 residents over a 14-day period can make ""all types of visits to Portugal, including even non-essential visits,"" the ministry said in a statement.  Tourists from Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland and Switzerland are also allowed to start flying to Portugal.  Visitors will have to show proof of a negative test taken up to 72 hours before a flight and airlines will be fined between €500 and €2,000 for each passenger who boards without presenting proof of a negative test.  The ministry said restrictions, limited to essential trips, would be maintained for five EU countries - Cyprus, Croatia, Lithuania, the Netherlands and Sweden - plus Brazil, India and South Africa.  Yesterday, Portugal said it will allow holidaymakers from Britain to enter the country from Monday (...) European Union rules prohibit non-essential travel from outside the bloc, making Portugal's decision to allow in UK tourists an exception.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210519023205/https://www.rte.ie/news/coronavirus/2021/0515/1221758-coronavirus-europe/

Previous measures are still in place.    In November 2020, the Government approved the ban on the suspension of essential services such water, electricity or gas during the first half of 2021, for those who are unemployed, have had a reduction in household income equal to or greater than 20%, or have been infected by Covid-19.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210323145814/https://www.dinheirovivo.pt/geral/covid-19-pagamento-faseado-de-energia-limitado-a-faturas-ate-30-de-junho-13409907.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210227072414/https://www.cgd.pt/Site/Saldo-Positivo/protecao/Pages/apoios-sociais-2021.aspx    ""The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for households and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak which has been extended until end-September 2021. The date by which households and companies can avail themselves of the moratoria was extended to end-March 2021.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213155040/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P    ""Under the extraordinary tenant protection regime during the pandemic evictions, complaints and opposition to the renewal of housing and commercial lease agreements will continue to be suspended until June 30, 2021. The extraordinary and transitional regime for the protection of tenants, which provides for the suspension of contract terminations by landlords and the end of the lease agreements (...) on December 22, 2020, the Government's bill was approved, which extends its effects until June 2021, due to the current situation in the country. In all cases, however, the granting of this extension of the regime depends on the payment of the rent due in the respective month. This, unless the tenants are covered by the rent deferral regime (...) this provision is valid for rents due in the months of October to December 2020, as well as in the months from January to June 2021. (...) In accordance with Law no. 75-A / 2020 , which changes the exceptional regime for situations of delay in the payment of rent, provision is made for flexibility in the payment of rents (due in the months of October to December 2020 and January to June 2021) by tenants who have proven to have a drop in income as a direct consequence of the pandemic. Thus, the rent moratorium depends on financial difficulties when the following conditions are met:  - A reduction of more than 20% in the tenants household income compared to the income of the previous month or the same period of the previous year;  - An effort rate made by the household greater than 30% (given the serious consequences of the pandemic, the Executive has reduced the effort rate from 35% to 30% by proceeding with the new amendment of Law 4/2020 in December 2020).""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210227074439/https://www.cgd.pt/Site/Saldo-Positivo/protecao/Pages/protecao-contra-acao-despejo.aspx
Ongoing public health campaign.    Sources: https://archive.vn/tsZz0  http://web.archive.org/web/20210522161332/https://covid19.min-saude.pt/

Most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1.   No changes regarding facial covering were announced. According to the Prime Minister, these will likely continue mandatory until the end of the summer, which is when herd immunity is expected to be achieved.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669

Previous policy remains in place. With regards to mask requirements in beaches, the Government decided to maintain the same regime established last year. The use of masks will mandatory when accessing beaches and on routes to and from the beach, including restaurants.   Sources http://web.archive.org/web/20210514220806/https://www.timeout.pt/lisboa/pt/coisas-para-fazer/o-estado-de-calamidade-foi-decretado-quais-sao-as-regras http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669

The Assistant Secretary of State for Health, António Lacerda Sales, announced on May 14, that masks will continue to be mandatory for fully vaccinated people. The decision to maintain the rules unchanged was justified by the lack of evidence regarding the possibility of vaccinated people transmitting the virus to those who are not yet vaccinated.    Source: https://archive.vn/5wgCG

Starting this Friday, April 23, individuals aged 65 or above (including those without any pre-existing conditions) will be able to chose the date and place of vaccination in the Health Directorate General portal. They will be able to accept the date suggested by the portal, chose another one or stay on the waiting list. Those who register in this portal will have to wait for an SMS that will confirm the date, time and place.     According to the government, 2,015,225 people have already taken the first dose, while 689,329 (representing approximately 7% of the population) already have complete vaccination against the virus SARS-CoV-2. By age group, 91% of the elderly over 80 years old (617,566 people) are already vaccinated with the first dose and 58% (394,186) have already received both doses of the vaccine. In the age group between 65 and 79 years old, 42% (669,263) also received the first dose of the vaccine a percentage that drops to just 4% (59,658) if we consider those who have taken the two doses.    Note: Upgraded to 4 since, according to the codebook ""Broad groups may include a large group of adults, for example those aged 50-65"". In this case, includes those aged 65-79.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514231120/https://www.jn.pt/nacional/pessoas-com-mais-65-anos-podem-agendar-vacinacao-a-partir-de-hoje-13603627.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210514232113/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/23/sociedade/noticia/65-anos-saiba-agendar-vacinacao-covid19-1959726

The Health Secreatary of State, António Lacerda Sales, announced that the Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, of the Johnson & Johnson group, will be recommended to people over 50 years old and will start start being administred now.     He added that the ongoing studies and the data that are still being analyzed by the European Medicines Agency can justify the revision of this recommendation at any time. Those who are under 50 can choose to receive the Janssen vaccine, as long as they are informed about the benefits and risks, and expressly give their consent.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173819/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/portugal-recomenda-vacina-da-johnson-para-pessoas-com-mais-de-50-anos--13629866.html

""""“In view of the good pace at which vaccination against Covid-19 has been taking place, it is reported that the possibility of self-scheduling is now available for ages 55 and over,"" says the 'task force' in a statement sent to newsrooms.  The measure to extend the age comes just four days after having opened on Sunday the appointment for over 60 years, a development that reflects the period of intensification of vaccination.""  According to the 'task force' schedule, vaccinations for this new age group should only start from next 24 May.  In a table presented on 27 April, at the last Infarmed meeting, the coordinator of the national vaccination plan against Covid-19, Gouveia e Melo, said that the goal for people between 60 and 69 years of age is that everyone has a dose of the vaccine by 23 May. Already for the group between 50 and 59 years, which includes part of the population now covered with the new extension of self-scheduling, the appointed date is 13 June.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514230829/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-05-14/self-scheduling-for-vaccine-now-available-to-people-over-55/59899

""The task force for vaccination against covid-19 in Portugal will implement a system that involves the initiation of simultaneous vaccination for various age groups with a one week interval between them, between the end of May and the beginning of June.  The over-50s will start to be vaccinated first; a week later jabs will start to be given to the over-40s, and one week later the over-30s.    The objective, according to reports, is to take advantage of Johnson & Johnson's vaccines for the over-50s, and use Pfizer and Moderna for other age groups.""    Source: https://archive.vn/Sy7Cn

The final phase of easing of lockdown for the majority of Portugal was antecipated 2 days and will now come in to force on Saturday, May 1, with much of the country returning to relative normality. However, the restrictions to care home visits will remain and day centers will remain closed. The measures will be reviewed in two weeks and there is no guarantee these will be lifted.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173312/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-04-30/portugal-moving-into-final-phase-of-lockdown/59652 http://web.archive.org/web/20201201082505/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2020-05-01-Restricoes-em-lares-mantem-se-visitas-continuam-canceladas

No change in policy; ""Public transportation is limited to 50% capacity.""  https://archive.vn/6vHPe

Testing available at the main public hospital (free) plus at private clinics (for a charge)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427102641/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

""Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina for 60-75 Euros; availability outside Pristina is unknown.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.""   https://archive.vn/6vHPe

couldn't find any convincing evidence of comprehensive tracing. 6 May ""The training was delivered as part of an ongoing initiative to increase the contact tracing workforce in Kosovo where contact tracing has been implemented from the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic by the Institute of Public Health and its regional branches, with support from WHO.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524142112/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/WOU_2021_17May_cleared1b443d1f1-4fd1-4aef-a6b4-4951fd4361e1.pdf

""1. Wearing a mask covering the nose and mouth is mandatory, in all cases except:  11.1.When driving alone or with close family members;  11.2. During running and cycling;  11.3 When walking outside residential areas and not in groups with more than 4 people of the same family.""  https://archive.vn/7XOeO

Which vaccines are available in Kosovo? Astra Zeneca.   At this time the vaccine is limited to health care workers, police, Kosovo Security Forces and those over 80 years of age.  (A,C)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412191748/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/    Kosovo which is the last country in Europe to start its vaccination rollout, and says it will start inoculating medical personnel, elderly citizens people, and those with chronic diseases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412215258/https://www.euronews.com/2021/03/29/kosovo-receives-first-covid-19-vaccines-through-covax-programme

AstraZeneca being used. It appears that key workers, those with chronic conditions, and people over 80 are currently being vaccinated (A, B, C).   ""With the arrival of today’s second batch, the rollout of the national deployment and vaccination plan will continue to priority groups such as remaining health workers, people with chronic diseases, and other priority groups as detailed in the plan.""  Source: https://archive.vn/4hysm     ""Phase one: Vaccination of high-risk groups consisting of health workers, residents and health workers of nursing homes, age groups 80+ and a part of the population with chronic diseases (people on dialysis, people with diabetes, diseases cardiovascular).""   https://archive.vn/WnteN    ""April 15 - The Ministry of Health (MoH) through an announcement has announced that on April 16 in Kosovo will begin vaccination of persons aged 75-79 years with chronic diseases...Meanwhile, vaccination of people over the age of 80 and health professionals is continuing.""  Source: https://archive.vn/NgtJO

Persons over 65 years of age are only allowed to leave their own apartment during the periods 6:00 to 10:00 and 16:00 to 19:00.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210511111947/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html

According to the ministerial order no.3.459/280/06.03.2021, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of cases is higher than 3/1000 inhabitants, but lower than 6/1000, the participation in classes is with physical presence for all preschoolers and primary school students, students from grades 8th, 12th, and 13th classes. If the threshold of 6/1000 is exceeded, the quarantine will be applied immediately, and all activities will be online.    Links:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315185439/https://www.edu.ro/modific%C4%83ri-ale-m%C4%83surilor-de-organizare-activit%C4%83%C5%A3ii-%C3%AEn-cadrul-unit%C4%83%C5%A3ilorinstitu%C5%A3iilor-de-%C3%AEnv%C4%83%C5%A3%C4%83m%C3%A2nt and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315185940/https://stirioficiale.ro/hotarari/hotarare-nr-15-din-05-03-2021

According to the ministerial order no.3755/29.04.2021 (which extends order no. 3235/93/2021), if the cumulative incidence of cases, in a locality for the last 14 days, is lower than 1/1000 inhabitants, the participation in classes will be physical presence for all preschoolers, primary school students and other groups of students. If it is higher than 1/1000, all activities will be online, except the students from grades 8th, 12th, and 13th classes.    Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20210509164637/https://www.edu.ro/sites/default/files/_fi%C8%99iere/Legislatie/2021/Ordin%20comun%20ME_MS_3755_2021.pdf

According to the Decision no.432/8.04.21, the organization and development of activity in cinemas, performance institutions and / or concerts are allowed with the participation of the public up to 50% of the maximum capacity of the space, if the incidence accumulated in the last 14 days of cases in the county / locality is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants. Also, the activity of restaurants and cafes inside hotels, boarding houses or other accommodation units is allowed without exceeding 50% of the maximum capacity of the space and in the time interval 6.00-22.00, in the counties / localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants, not exceeding 30% of the maximum capacity of the space.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210418150432/http://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocument/240862

According to the Decision no.432/8.04.21, the organization and outdoor performance of shows, concerts, public and private festivals, or other cultural events are allowed only with the participation of up to 300 spectators with seats, at a distance of at least 2 meters from each other, as well as wearing a protective mask. Activities are prohibited in counties / localities where the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of cases is higher than 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants. According to Order 29/14.05.2021, cultural, artistic and entertainment activities can be organized in open spaces with the participation of up to 1000 people, with a minimum area of 2 m2 for each person and compliance with health protection measures if the incidence of 14 days of cases in the county/locality is less than or equal to 3/1000 inhabitants. Sport competitions in open spaces can have up to 25% of the maximum capacity. Competitions with public participation in enclosed spaces is still forbidden. Additionally, recreational outdoor and sporting activities are prohibited, except for those carried out with the participation of no more than 10 persons not living together. According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours. There are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions). Travelers with a point of departure in a high-risk country must present a negative PT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2, performed no more than 72 hours before boarding a flight and no more than 72 hours before entry in Romania for people arriving by car. The National Institute of Public Health published a new list of states with high epidemiological risk. The decisions no. 432/8.04.2021 of National Committee for Emergency Situations contains the required conditions for the passengers coming in Romania from countries with high epidemiological risk.   Link https://web.archive.org/web/20210418152320/https://stirioficiale.ro/hotarari/hotarare-nr-22-din-08-04-2021-a-cnsu, https://web.archive.org/web/20210502063021/http://www.cnscbt.ro/index.php/liste-zone-afectate-covid-19 and https://web.archive.org/web/20210502062250/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

There are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions). Travelers with a point of departure in a high-risk country must present a negative PT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2, performed no more than 72 hours before boarding a flight and no more than 72 hours before entry in Romania for people arriving by car. The National Institute of Public Health published a new list of states with high epidemiological risk. The decisions no. 432/8.04.2021 of National Committee for Emergency Situations contains the required conditions for the passengers coming in Romania from countries with high epidemiological risk.   Link https://web.archive.org/web/20210418152320/https://stirioficiale.ro/hotarari/hotarare-nr-22-din-08-04-2021-a-cnsu, https://web.archive.org/web/20210502063021/http://www.cnscbt.ro/index.php/liste-zone-afectate-covid-19 and https://web.archive.org/web/20210502062250/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315184742/https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers. According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315184933/https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315185046/https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, the National Information Platform on vaccination against COVID-19 was released.  Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193144/https://archive.fo/cUlEp , https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193218/https://archive.fo/klswT, https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193322/https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193430/https://archive.fo/O0MTX

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193619/https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193759/https://archive.fo/thRdi  and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193827/https://archive.fo/FUhtr

On 15th of March, the third stage of the vaccination program for the general population began. Also, on 15th of March, the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 decided to continue the vaccination campaign in Romania will all vaccines against COVID-19, following the analysis of the adverse reaction reports registered in Romania and the recommendations of the European Medicines Agency. Foreign students from 25 countries can return to Russia for their studies. They must notify their university by email 10 days ahead of arrival and submit two coronavirus tests 72 hours before and after landing in Russia.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210327222014/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/03/27/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-march-27-a69117

No new policies. While there are no more closures, classrooms and school are still under reduced capacity guidelines. Since April 12th all schools, all levels can be in-person.  Via DECREE LAW 8 April 2021 n.63: On Friday, April 9, 2021 and Saturday, April 10, 2021, distance learning is scheduled for 50% of the second and third classes of the Middle School and for all classes of the Secondary School and the Vocational Training Center (CFP). Beginning Monday, April 12, 2021, the Middle School, the Secondary School and the Vocational Training Center (CFP) will return to 100% face-to-face instruction. On days when distance learning is present, teachers will hold classes, depending on the organizational model adopted by the specific school order, either on site or in smart working. For students with disabilities, lessons continue to be held in the classroom.    Early Childhood Social Educational Services will continue 100% in-person instructional activities. The Preschool and Elementary School, effective Friday, April 9, 2021, shall return to 100% in-person instructional activities. For the term of this decree-law, the Preschools shall close at 4:30 p.m. The Secretary of State for Education and Culture, after consultation with the relevant health authorities, may modify the closing time by means of a circular of his own.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165746/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124053.html

For non-vaccinated teaching and non-teaching staff of all types and levels, there is an obligation to wear the mask continuously inside or  outside the school building.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210524205011/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124623.html

From April 30th, DECREE - LAW n.85  The start date of the agile working arrangements for the private sector is postponed to June 1, 2021. Therefore, the ""work from home"" modalities referred to in article 6 of Decree-Law no. 122 of July 24, 2020 remain extended until this date.  The ""work from home"" agreements entered into pursuant to Decree-Law no. 122/2020 will cease to have effect as of June 1, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165746/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124053.html

From April 30th, DECREE - LAW n.85  Theaters, museums, libraries and places of culture are open to the public, which must be arranged by occupying the seats in an alternating manner in order to ensure compliance with the distances, with the exception of those belonging to the same household and those who are vaccinated.    Events, including sporting events, parties, shows and entertainment events held in public and private places both outdoors and indoors are permitted in compliance with the guidelines defined in specific Regulations adopted by the State Congress on the proposal of the Prevention Department of the Social Security Institute and Civil Protection and issued by the Regency.    Parties and events involving dancing may be held outdoors only with access restricted to vaccinated participants only.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165746/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124053.html

In San Marino, the restrictions from decrees 206/2020 and 85/2021 initially apply until June 3, 2021 .    Gatherings of more than four people from the same household in private and public places are not permitted. The maximum number does not apply if all participants are vaccinated. Restaurants, cafes, bars and shops as well as museums, cinemas and theaters can open under special conditions.     It is compulsory to wear a mask, both outdoors and indoors. Failure to comply with the obligations relating to the proper use of the mask is punished with an administrative fine of € 500.00 with the possibility of voluntary oblation.  Remote connection methods are recommended wherever possible when holding meetings and assemblies. Meetings, conferences, congresses, meetings, conventions and the like are permitted in compliance with the health and hygiene measures in force with particular regard to interpersonal distancing and the proper use of personal protective equipment. The limitations referred to in this paragraph shall not apply if all participants are vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510193002/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/laender/sanmarino-node/sanmarinosicherheit/227014  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510191327/https://www.visitsanmarino.com/en/visitnews/Informazioni-utili-COVID-19.html
No change, please see previous entry.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165746/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124053.html

No new policies.  When entering San Marino who have stayed outside Italy and the Vatican in the previous 14 days, a negative PCR or antigen test, which must not be older than 48 hours, or a certificate of a SARS-CoV-2 vaccination carried out or via existing SARS-CoV-2 antibodies after April 1, 2021 or via recovery from SARS-CoV-2 disease within the last 6 months.  Entry into San Marino from an Italian red or orange zone is only permitted in cases of necessity, health or work. There are no restrictions on entering San Marino from a designated yellow zone.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510193002/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/laender/sanmarino-node/sanmarinosicherheit/227014  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510200214/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus
