No new policies. Continuing policies include government allowing individuals and firms affected by the COVID-19 crisis to defer payments of loan principals to banks until March 2021. Commercial banks are providing loans with reduced rates to individuals and firms who are impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak. Through the end of the year, the government provides guarantees on loans with reduced rates to households (90 percent for loans up to 10,000 euros and 3 years maturity) and firms (70 percent for loans up to 500,000 euros and 6 years maturity) to support liquidity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510190250/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510190250/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No new policies. Continuing from April 1 2021: The key measures approved by the government include: i) suspension of payment deadlines for government tax and non-tax obligations, utility bills, and other dues to provide liquidity to the private sector; ii) temporary freeze of all non-essential government spending and reduction in public sector wage bill to redirect spending to the health sector; and iii) extension of supplemental wage scheme to support workers displaced by COVID-19 containment measures; iv) deferral of income tax payment; v) minimum guaranteed income for poorer households; vi) other measures to support businesses, including tax credits, tax payments postponement and rescheduling; vii) an economic recovery fund, financed initially through a temporary solidarity levy applied on pensions (above 1500 euros). Supplemental wage measures instituted to tackle the pandemic have been extended to June 2021. In March 2021, the authorities have adopted a stimulus package of 18 million euros (1.5 percent of GDP),which includes, among other, grants for businesses that have experienced at least a 30 percent loss in revenues during the pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510190250/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No policy changes. Citizens of San Marino, people who have their place of residence or habitual abode in San Marino and who are returning to San Marino from countries other than Italy and the Vatican or who have stayed outside of these two countries in the previous 14 days, must enter the ""Centro Unico Prenotazioni dell'ISS ""/"" Single Booking Center ""(phone 00378 (0) 549 994889 or e-mail) so that you can register within 48 hours of entry COVID-19-Test can be performed. Alternatively, the ""Laboratorio Analisi dell'ISS"" can report a negative result of a PCR or antigen test or a certificate of the SARS-CoV-2 vaccination or of existing SARS-CoV-2 antibodies after April 1, 2021 or of the Recovery from SARS_CoV-2 disease within the last 6 months must be presented. The test must have been carried out within 48 hours before entering San Marino. Until the test result is received, the persons must go into fiduciary quarantine (autoisolamento fiduciario). If the test result is positive, the quarantine must take place at home (isolamento domiciliare). The cost of the test and the quarantine are to be borne by the travelers. Failure to comply with the notification and quarantine requirements will result in heavy fines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510193002/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/laender/sanmarino-node/sanmarinosicherheit/227014

DECREE - LAW 30 April 2021 n.85  The Institute for Social Security guarantees free vaccination campaign in progress, for the categories of citizens, residents and residents eligible, for reservations received by May 31, 2021. After that date, the vaccination service will be provided at a cost of € 50.00 (fifty/00). No change in policy.  All businesses and services that are allowed to work, may operate from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.  Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens or patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables.  Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed.  Cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed, but may sell take-away food and drinks over the counter. Delivery services may be provided 24-hours a day.  All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses.  Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503180001/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

As of May 7th, bars and restaurants will be allowed to work indoors until 10pm, at 50 percent capacity, respecting the distance of 1.5 to 2 meters and without music. Previous policy restricted businesses to operate outdoors only.     Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables. Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed. Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed.  However, all cafes, bars and restaurants may continue to sell take-away food and drinks over the counter.  Delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person.  Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses. Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510082941/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/172177/bars-restaurants-to-start-working-indoors-as-of-tomorrow.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510083045/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510184716/https://www.osac.gov/Content/Report/b12c51a2-24a2-4e39-ba05-1b484bff5155

No change in policy since May 7th:     Bars and restaurants will be allowed to work indoors until 10pm, at 50 percent capacity, respecting the distance of 1.5 to 2 meters and without music. Previous policy restricted businesses to operate outdoors only.     Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables. Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed. Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed.  However, all cafes, bars and restaurants may continue to sell take-away food and drinks over the counter.  Delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person.  Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses. Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510082941/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/172177/bars-restaurants-to-start-working-indoors-as-of-tomorrow.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510083045/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510184716/https://www.osac.gov/Content/Report/b12c51a2-24a2-4e39-ba05-1b484bff5155

A supplementary budget with new support measures was adopted in April 2021. New measures include: (i) wage subsidies, including payment of ½ of minimum wages for all entrepreneurs and employees in SMEs and large companies for three months (RSD 69.8 billion); (ii) additional payments for employees in travel, hospitality, and art (RSD 4.4 billion); (iii) universal cash transfer of EUR 60 to each citizen over 18 years old, paid in two installments of EUR 30 each—in May and November (RSD 43.2 billion);(iv) a one-off payment of EUR 50 to all pensioners (RSD 10 billion);(v)a one-off financial assistance of EUR 60 to all the unemployed, paid in June (RSD 4.3 billion); and (vi) support for the transport sector and for city hotels (RSD 3.9bn).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524002614/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

From April 26, the education sector follows the regional COVID automat system:  - black tier districts: only kindergartens, grades one-four of primary schools, and secondary health schools will be open, while it will be possible to organise in-person education in small groups of five pupils and one teacher if there are problems with distance learning;  - dark red tier districts: kindergartens, grades one-four of primary schools, secondary health schools, plus grades eight and nine of primary schools, counselling centres, free time centres and language schools for individual education will be open;  - red tier districts: kindergartens, grades one-nine of primary schools, secondary health schools, first four grades of eight-year grammar schools, plus all the other facilities in the previous tier will be open;  - light red tier districts: kindergartens, primary schools, secondary schools, language schools, free time centres and art schools for group learning will be open.  The Education Ministry will also open summer schools this summer so that pupils can catch up with the schoolwork.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511153252/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22636516/schools-will-open-for-more-pupils-on-april-19.html
partially open; source: /web/20210524101957/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Restaurants and fitness centres are allowed to open as of April 26 2021.   A negative COVID test and wearing a mask will be required in restaurants. Tables must be 2 metres distant from each other. Clients will be required to sit while eating and drinking. There is no indication as to who can sit at one table, not restricted to members of just one household.  Fitness centers can only let in six clients at a time. They are required to increase the frequency at which they clean and disinfect surfaces. Clients are not required to wear masks while exercising.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511162738/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22645102/negative-test-will-be-required-for-restaurant-terraces.html

As of 10 May 2021,  Services that remain closed: natural and artificial swimming pools; facilities providing wellness services (saunas, whirlpools, spas, wraps); fitness centers; operation of theater, music, exterior film or other artistic performances, which are located in the territorial districts of the districts in III. warning levels; catering operations; operation of interior film performances.  Since 19 April 2021, all shops and services have reopened, with strict measures including only 1 customer per 15 square metres; customers must show a negative Covid test no older than 7 days to enter.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511154546/https://korona.gov.sk/prevadzky-sluzby-a-hromadne-podujatia/

People will be allowed to travel from 8:00 p.m. to 1:00 a.m. only to work or to see a doctor, while all currently valid exceptions from the limits on movement will be effective only between 5:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. People who can work from home should do so. If the tougher restrictions do not curb infections by March 21, the government will prepare even stricter limits on movement, including closure of companies and borders; source: /web/20210524135612/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-slovakia-idUSKCN2AS0QS

From May 3 2021, cultural events for more than 6 people can be held in red and light red districts. This includes theatre performances, outdoor screenings, concerts and various audiovisual events, exhibitions and festivals, but not balls or open-air markets.  Cultural events are still allowed for a seated audience only.  Cultural events in burgundy districts are still prohibited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510103052/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22646282/slovakia-is-gradually-opening-up-what-covid-measures-are-in-place.html

- Cultural events are still prohibited in the 2 burgundy districts, Považská Bystrica and Myjava.  - The permitted number of spectators at cultural events in the red and pink districts is increasing. A maximum of 50 percent of the capacity is still allowed to be filled. In the red districts, there can be up to 200 participants outdoors and 150 indoors. In the pink regions, up to 500 spectators are allowed outdoors and 250 indoors.  - Cultural events cannot be aimed at school-age minors or school groups.  - Physical interactive play with the audience is not allowed.  - Standing is prohibited.  - Participants in cultural events must have a negative RT-PCR / LAMP test not older than 72 hours or an antigen test not older than 24 hours, with the exception of children under 10 years of age, vaccinations and persons who have overcome COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510100709/https://www.minv.sk/?tlacove-spravy=&sprava=covid-automat-pravidla-a-vynimky-zo-zakazu-vychadzania-ucinne-od-10-maja

People will be allowed to travel from 8:00 p.m. to 1:00 a.m. only to work or to see a doctor, while all currently valid exceptions from the limits on movement will be effective only between 5:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. source: /web/20210524135612/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-slovakia-idUSKCN2AS0QS; Cultural and sports events scrapped, tourist attractions closed; source: /web/20210524140419/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22354110/coronavirus-sports-and-cultural-events-cancelled-in-slovakia.html

No change in policy. Several measures have be lifted from 19 April 2021 as the country switched to the dark red tier of its Covid automat alert system.  In dark red districts, public events are still forbidden except for Church services that will be allowed with one person per 15 square metres and a negative test no older than 7 days. Parties, weddings, funeral feasts remain prohibited.  In red and light red districts, mass events are permitted for a maximum of 6 people with exception for cinemas, theatres, concert halls and masses.  No district have been declared to be at a lower level of restrictions yet.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419194702/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22637661/measures-will-be-lifted-from-april-19-what-will-open.html?ref=njctse

Public transportation is operating. Masks are required on all forms of public transportation. Taxi and ride sharing app services are available, and also require the use of FFP2/K95/N95 face masks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510090537/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Starting Monday May 3, only districts in the dark red tier will keep curfew rules between 5:00 and 1:00.  Districts in the red tier and light red tier will only have evening curfew, meaning that there will be restrictions between 21:00 and 1:00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511165508/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22648739/curfew-rules-will-change-most-restrictions-will-be-kept-only-in-districts-in-a-bad-situation.html

From Monday May 10 2021, Slovakia enters the pink phase of the COVID tiers. Two districts, Považská Bystrica and Myjava, remain burgundy, with 33 districts in red and 44 in pink. Stricter rules still need to be observed in burgundy districts, where curfew is in place from 5 am to 1 am. In the pink and red districts, there is only an evening curfew - from 9 pm to 1 am.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510100709/https://www.minv.sk/?tlacove-spravy=&sprava=covid-automat-pravidla-a-vynimky-zo-zakazu-vychadzania-ucinne-od-10-maja

People will be allowed to travel from 8:00 p.m. to 1:00 a.m. only to work or to see a doctor, while all currently valid exceptions from the limits on movement will be effective only between 5:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. People who can work from home should do so; source:  /web/20210524135612/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-slovakia-idUSKCN2AS0QS

No change in policy. Travel between districts is allowed since 19 April 2021, however a negative test not older than 7 days is still required.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511160051/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22648739/curfew-rules-will-change-most-restrictions-will-be-kept-only-in-districts-in-a-bad-situation.html

If you enter the territory of the Slovak Republic from April 26, 2021:  - you are obliged to enter the home isolation until you receive a negative result of the RT-PCR test for COVID-19, no earlier than the eighth day of home isolation  - if you are traveling from a country that is a member of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein, Switzerland or the United Kingdom (and you have only visited these countries in the last 14 days) and you have an asymptomatic course, your home isolation ends when you reach the 14th day, even though you do not receive a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19  - If you are traveling from outside the EU, you must remain in isolation until you receive a negative test result  - Home isolation is also obligatory for people living with you in the same household  - you are also required to report by telephone to the regional public health office or electronically by registering via the eHranica form and to your healthcare provider (ie GP / pediatrician) with whom you have a contract.  - if you enter the territory of the Slovak Republic by air, you are also obliged to fill in an electronic form to search for a passenger  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510173554/https://www.mzv.sk/cestovanie/covid19/obmedzenia-na-hraniciach
Operating with limitations; guidelines on testing and quarantine as outlined in the entry and exit requirements; source: /web/20210524141227/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in the policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511104044/https://www.pomahameludom.sk/    ""Measures introduced by the coalition government include (i) wage compensation for affected businesses and self-employed, and subsidies to individuals without income (subsequently extended to June 2021 and augmented in size); (ii) enhanced unemployment benefits, and sickness and nursing benefits; (iii) deferral and waiver of employers' social security contributions for some months for affected companies and self-employed (deferral extended to June 2021); (iv) easing of the administrative burden on businesses and relaxing labor code requirements; (v) deferral of payroll and corporate tax payments for businesses whose revenues decline by more than 40 percent; (vi) allowing companies to include loss carryback since 2014; (vii) rental subsidies; and (viii) higher medical spending.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511103716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No update; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210511104044/https://www.pomahameludom.sk/

No change in the policy. no updates; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210511103716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The state of emergency declared in the country since September 2020 will be extended for another 30 days, at least until the end of May 2021. The government decided to do so at an online meeting on Monday, April 26, 2021. The state of emergency was to end on April 28.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511150315/https://www.minv.sk/?tlacove-spravy=&sprava=nudzovy-stav-kabinet-predlzil-o-30-dni-zakaz-vychadzania-bude-az-po-21-hodine
No reliable source found.

Residents and visitors can also undergo free rapid antigen testing in each district upon request at facilities listed on the e-VUC website, many of which take walk-in patients.  Appointments for rapid antigen tests can also be scheduled at these facilities.  Requests for tests can also be sent to the Ministry of Health via the COVID-19 website.  Clinic staff provide hand-written results certificates to patients immediately after their tests, or may provide results electronically after registration. Persons who take a test from one of the Slovak government’s approved clinics may receive an SMS message with their test results. It can take up to three days to receive PCR results.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510090537/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Thorough testing policy; source: /web/20210524141227/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy found since contact tracing measures were put in place in October 2020.  People testing positive to COVID should report their close contacts. The Regional Public Health Authority will automatically get in touch with the contacts.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510172845/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22506791/i-encountered-a-person-who-is-covid-19-positive-what-do-i-do-next-faq.html

FFP2 or KN95 respirators are still required inside buildings, including shops.  People can wear masks outside and take them off if they are with members of the same household or if people from outside their household are more than 5 metres away.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510103052/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22646282/slovakia-is-gradually-opening-up-what-covid-measures-are-in-place.html

As of April 26, 2021, higher education institutions and student dormitories will open, without any restrictions or exceptions set so far. A hybrid model is recommended , ie a combined implementation of study activities with live and distance implementation, in accordance with the capabilities of the higher education institution and the needs of the study process.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426213121/https://www.gov.si/novice/2021-04-22-prihodnji-teden-se-odpirajo-tudi-visokosolski-zavodi-in-studentski-domovi/    On 8 of April, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia decided that toddlers can return to kindergartens, and pupils and students can return to schools starting from  April 12, which was communicated by Minister Kustec. The organisation and implementation of lessons in kindergartens, primary and secondary schools next week will take place in the same manner as before the closure. This means that all pupils will return to primary schools, while secondary school students will return in accordance with model C, which means alternate weeks of school attendance and remote learning at home. School dormitories will open on Sunday. The use of protective masks is mandatory for pupils in grades 6 to 9, the staff and secondary school students, while pupils in grades 1 to 5 must wear masks in common areas and when moving through the school. Pupils and students are not obliged to wear masks during physical education.     https://archive.vn/Fbmhj

Classes for primary and secondary school students are to be held on school premises.  Activities in secondary schools are running according to Model B, i.e. on school or other educational institution premises, and students can stay in residential facilities full time. All classes at higher vocational colleges can be conducted face-to-face. There are no changes regarding mask-wearing and employee testing.     https://archive.vn/T26Kt

Classes for primary and secondary school students are to be held on school premises.  Activities in secondary schools are running according to Model B, i.e. on school or other educational institution premises, and students can stay in residential facilities full time. All classes at higher vocational colleges can be conducted face-to-face. There are no changes regarding mask-wearing and employee testing.     https://archive.vn/T26Kt

Starting April 26, outdoor spaces of restaurants and other catering establishments will be allowed to reopen in ""orange"" regions, and both outdoor and indoor spaces of such establishments will be allowed to reopen in ""yellow"" regions. Furthermore, accommodation facilities with up to 30 rooms will be allowed to reopen in orange regions, while all accommodation facilities can reopen in yellow regions. As of April 21, Obalno-Kraska, Goriska, and Pomurska regions are classified as yellow while the rest of the country is classified orange.    Most nonessential businesses are open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426213848/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/470106/slovenia-authorities-to-ease-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-april-23-update-33

The offering and sale of goods and services is permitted only in exceptional cases. The offering and sale of goods and services within the group of exceptions that demand a test is permitted only if the employees are tested once a week for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) using the HAG (rapid test) or PCR method. Goods and services can therefore be offered and sold only by employees who have a negative test result obtained in the Republic of Slovenia. All employees must be tested, including those who do not have direct contact with consumers.   Food and drinks are allowed to be served at outdoor terraces of catering establishments, provided the precautionary measures are observed.  Only guests who have one of the following proofs may stay inside catering facilities: a certificate of a negative SARS-CoV-2 virus test result; a proof of vaccination against COVID-19, proving that the following time has passed since the vaccination; a proof of a positive PCR test result that is older than 10 days but not older than six months, or a doctor’s certificate stating that they recovered from COVID-19 and that no more than six months have passed since the onset of symptoms.    https://archive.vn/f0wVe  https://archive.vn/T26Kt

Given the more favourable epidemiological picture, the Government based on prior consultation with the economy and expert group on COVID-19 decided to further release restrictions on catering, tourism and gambling activities. All changes will apply from Monday, 17 May.  From that day on, catering will be allowed from 5 a.m. to 10 p.m. The distance between the edges of the tables must be at least 3 metres. However, the distance between persons sitting at the table is no longer specified. The condition of four persons per table in catering establishments shall no longer apply to families with children under 18 years. Gambling halls may operate again, and special gambling may be organised. The working hours and conditions of entry into the indoor premises in the gaming sector are the same as for the catering establishments (reconvalescents, vaccinated, tested).  The working time shall also be set between 5 a.m. and 10 p.m. Gambling halls may offer up to 50 per cent of their available capacity, i.e. half of the gaming sites.      https://archive.vn/T26Kt

All events are banned. Sports matches may only take place in empty stadiums. Outdoor amateur team sports are prohibited. Individual sports activities are permitted. No more than 10 people can attend a family gathering or private event. Minors under 14 are exceptions from this limitation. Funerals can be attended by up to 50 people at a time. At weddings only the witnesses, parents and siblings may attend the ceremony and receptions are banned.    https://archive.vn/8e0IL

At weddings only the witnesses, parents and siblings may attend the ceremony and receptions are banned.    https://archive.vn/8e0IL

According to the Government decision from 15 May, attending events and gatherings is allowed with up to a maximum of 50 participants. Sport recreational activities may be carried out individually or in groups up to a maximum of 50 participants.   The gathering of persons in cultural institutions is allowed according to the square footage of the premises and the restriction of the collection of up to 50 persons. Outdoor or indoor cultural events may take place under the following conditions:  •	the provision of seating places is mandatory;  •	seating places may, taking into account the instructions of the NIJZ, be 50 per cent occupied;  •	employees need to continue testing once a week;  •	visitors may attend an event subject to the condition of RVT (except for any persons younger than 18 years of age accompanied by adults);  •	limitation to square footage and limits of gatherings for cultural events does not apply.  Regarding the exercise of religious freedom, the collection of up to 50 persons in outdoor and indoor areas is allowed again. A maximum of 50 per cent of seat occupancy is allowed, and participants who are not part of the same household must maintain a distance of 1.5 m.    https://archive.vn/f0wVe  https://archive.vn/f0wVe

From Monday, 17 May, and all sports competitions, whether for recreational athletes or registered athletes, are to be allowed. The presence of viewers in competitions is also possible again, in line with the restrictions. Sport recreational activities may be carried out individually or in groups up to a maximum of 50 participants.     https://archive.vn/f0wVe

Countries with an unstable epidemiological situation or administrative divisions of countries are included on the red list. People entering the Republic of Slovenia from these countries shall, due to potential infection with SARS-CoV-2 virus, be required to remain in quarantine for a period of ten (10) days. But there are some exceptions which are listed in detail on the Government of Slovenia official page.   The Police has launched a web application called Enter Slovenia to facilitate travelling to Slovenia. It is intended for passengers travelling to Slovenia or entering the country in order to transit through its territory.     https://archive.vn/qLIM5

No change found.   On February 3, 2021, an eight package (EUR 320 mn) was approved, which extends the furlough till April and the short-time work scheme till June. The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 per cent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517132036/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available throughout the country, including Ljubljana airport.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 5-30 euro; cost for PCR is 93 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210517133015/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Contact tracing is still in place in Slovenia.   #OstaniZdrav, a mobile app designed to protect health and human lives, can also help us contain the spread of infection as it notifies users of contact with an infected person.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517134526/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Masks are mandatory: in all closed public spaces, on public transport, in open public spaces or outside, if a distance of at least 1,5 metres is not maintained and in personal vehicles.    From 12 April 2021, protective masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, on public transport, in open places and outside where a distance of 1.5 metres cannot be maintained and in private vehicles when travelling with members of other households for work purposes. Masks are not compulsory for children under the age of six, primary school pupils up to 5th grade when in classrooms, and people practicing non-contact sports, if a distance of 3 metres can be maintained.     https://archive.vn/T26Kt   https://archive.vn/Z54UT

Per Slovenian government announcement, vaccination administration began with health care workers, critical infrastructure workers, and vulnerable populations. For the general population, Slovenia is currently vaccinating those age 60+.  According to the announcement, vaccines are available to all residents of Slovenia (but not visitors), regardless of insurance status. Following vaccines are administered: Astra-Zenica, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech.   Vaccination is free of charge and provided to all who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia and not only for citizens of the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517133015/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools are open, but principals of upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) have the possibility to switch to distance learning if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507145905/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507145907/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/    Coded as 1T because in several regions, recommendations are stricter. E.g.:   - The regional health agency (Smittskyddsläkaren) for Kalmar recommends a combination of partial distance and partial on-site education in upper secondary schools for 1 April - 16 May. ""The recommendation is reviewed on an ongoing basis."" -- http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150013/https://www.regionkalmar.se/kontakta-oss/kontakta-sjukvarden/coronaviruset/  - In Västra Götaland, upper secondary schools can have no more than two thirds of their pupils physically present. In the event of an outbreak or increased local spread of infection, schools may need to further reduce face-to-face teaching. Extended until 16 May. -- http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150129/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/skarpta-rekommendationer-i-vastra-gotaland-forlangs-till-16-maj/  - In Östergötland, ""teaching is currently done partly on site, partly at a distance. School activities are completely transferred to distance if there are local outbreaks, it can be a class, a part of a school or a whole school."" -- http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150153/https://www.1177.se/Ostergotland/aktuellt/aktuellt-i-ostergotland/30-april-personlig-lockdown-i-tva-veckor/    The Public Health Agency has also issued guidelines for graduation ceremonies in 2021, stating that large gatherings and crowding should be avoided: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150151/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/infor-studentexamen-2021/

Schools are open, but principals of upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) have the possibility to switch to distance learning if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175435/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507145907/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/    Coded as 1T because in several regions, recommendations are stricter. On 22 April, the Public Health Agency announced it will postpone its planned easing of covid restrictions due to ongoing high infection rates and the high pressure on hospitals, until 17 May.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191705/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/smittspridningen-kraver-forlangda-restriktioner/    This means that the limit of eight people at public events will not be raised on May 3rd as planned, and other restrictions, for example rules that make restaurants close by 8.30pm and regulate how many customers are allowed in shops at the same time, will also be extended. The Public Health Agency had originally hoped to lift restrictions on the number of people allowed at public events and gatherings by April 11th, but this was later postponed to May 3rd.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191719/https://www.thelocal.se/20210422/will-sweden-ease-coronavirus-restrictions-next-month-or-not/

No change:   Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs. As amusement parks of a permanent nature ('stadigvarande tivolinöje') remain covered by the 8-people gathering limit, other rules re restriction of numbers of visitors, which apply to non-permanent amusement parks, zoos, museums, etc., do not apply.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150207/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=90709#_90709     Between 1 March and 2 May, restaurants and cafés must be closed for consumption on site between 20.30 and 05.00. The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 4 people. If a party is larger than 8 people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.     Shops, gym and sports facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². The maximum number of visitors is 500. They must have clear signs about how many are allowed to stay in the room at the same time.     Department stores and shops must take appropriate measures for people to visit the business one by one, without company. Shopping centres are an exception because they may house workplaces, care facilities and public transport services that cannot be accessed in any other way.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210507150144/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud     https://web.archive.org/web/20210507150208/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-gallande-restauranger-och-krogar/

No change:   The government has introduced a number of restrictions in connection with the pandemic law. Until further notice, no more than 8 people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than 8 attendees. If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend. An exception is made for funerals, where up to 20 participants are allowed. If you organise an event in violation of the ban, you may face a fine or prison sentence of up to six months. Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150144/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150601/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/     In several regions, stricter regional measures dictate to ""avoid all unnecessary travel to, from and within the region"". There is a ban on unnecessary travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. The ban applies until 31 May 2021.  The entry ban does not apply to Swedish citizens or citizens of another EU / EEA country. Citizens of another EU / EEA country must present a maximum of 48 hours old negative covid-19 test. There are exceptions to the test requirement . Swedish citizens are recommended to test themselves after a stay abroad.  Swedish border inspectors decide how the exceptions are to be interpreted and what decisions are to be made. It is the traveler's own responsibility to be able to prove his right to an exception in border control. It is therefore necessary to be able to present, for example, employment certificates or extracts from the population register.     In addition, the following recommendation applies to everyone, including Swedes:   The Public Health Agency recommends everyone who travels into Sweden , regardless of citizenship, to test themselves upon entry and to avoid contacts for seven days. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry. Stay home for at least seven days. Avoid contact with others as much as possible. Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150628/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:  There is a ban on unnecessary travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. The ban applies until 31 May 2021.  The entry ban does not apply to Swedish citizens or citizens of another EU / EEA country. Citizens of another EU / EEA country must present a maximum of 48 hours old negative covid-19 test. There are exceptions to the test requirement . Swedish citizens are recommended to test themselves after a stay abroad.  Swedish border inspectors decide how the exceptions are to be interpreted and what decisions are to be made. It is the traveler's own responsibility to be able to prove his right to an exception in border control. It is therefore necessary to be able to present, for example, employment certificates or extracts from the population register.     In addition, the following recommendation applies to everyone, including Swedes:   The Public Health Agency recommends everyone who travels into Sweden , regardless of citizenship, to test themselves upon entry and to avoid contacts for seven days. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry. Stay home for at least seven days. Avoid contact with others as much as possible. Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175849/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change:  Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 April 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175859/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150633/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150628/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:   The regions of Blekinge, Örebro, Gävleborg, Halland, Norrbotten, Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, and Västra Götaland have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.     This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language (""must always be worn"") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150606/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

**Updated to clarify that this should not be a 4 code (which is why it was flagged) as this variable is coded according to the lowest common value if there is geographic variation, and only a few regions have the vaccine available to a broad group.**    Original note:    A,B,C:  Many regions are in phase 3, and a few areas have advanced to phase 4 for people over 55 years old. ""Stockholm is the first big city region to start Phase 4, after Kalmar, Jönköping and Värmland began it earlier this week. In Västra Götaland, some individual centres have opened up vaccination to under-60s, with Skåne saying it aims to offer the vaccine to all adults from mid-June onwards.""  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150720/https://www.thelocal.se/20210506/stockholm-starts-phase-4-of-covid-19-vaccinations/    Information on phases:   Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy.  Phase 3 initially means everyone over 60, and later will also include over-18s who have certain underlying health conditions, including chronic heart, lung, liver or kidney disease, severe asthma, diabetes, health conditions that cause impaired lung functioning (for example extreme obesity, neuromuscular diseases or multiple disabilities), Down syndrome, or people with a severely weakened immune system due to illness or ongoing medical treatment.  In Phase 4, all adults will be offered the vaccine, but it will still be offered in a staggered way, opened up to five-year age groups at a time.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150708/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn    The Public Health Agency has clarified that in each of these phases, the oldest people should be vaccinated first. Healthcare professionals that receive priority are those at great risk of infecting patients, i.e. those in daily or prolonged contact with patients in a risk group: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150756/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/fortydligande-om-vaccination-av-medarbetare-i-halso--och-sjukvard/     Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150606/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. ""The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered.""  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin    - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/  But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/    - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150823/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/    Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210506233027/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include: - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms. - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit. - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors. - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150856/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150911/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

No evidence for current policies (April 2021) on debt relief for households.   ___________________________    Quote (1):  The Government is providing VAT exemptions on essential imports, lump-sum assistance equivalent to minimum wage to vulnerable households and other socially disadvantaged groups. Health workers are to receive supplemental pay, while tariff increases on electricity, water, and communal services have been postponed until end of 2020. Government is providing free medical care to citizens placed under medical care and COVID-19 patients, as well as sick leave and compensation benefits. Government is providing grain, seed and fuel to farms to boost food security, and time-bound tax holidays and relief to targeted industries and small businesses until September 1, 2020. Anti-COVID measures also include financial support to SMEs and subsidizing food for population. Recently, Tajikistan was granted a debt relief around USD50 million under G20 DSSI initiative. These funds were also included to anti-COVID envelop under supplementary budget currently being discussed in the Parliament.""    Link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.04.12-143712/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

""Direct flights from Brazil and South Africa remain cancelled:?   All passengers traveling through another country who have been in Brazil and South Africa in the last 10 days will continue to be quarantined in places determined by the governorships for a period of 14 days following their entry into Turkey.   PCR tests will be performed on the 10th day of the quarantine period and the quarantine of those who have negative test results will be ended at the end of the 10th day, the treatment of those who have a positive PCR test will be carried out in accordance with the Ministry of Health COVID 19 guidelines; the quarantine of those who do not have the PCR test will be completed after 14 days.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510184523/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Foreign tourists who are in Turkey for a temporary period within the scope of touristic activities will be exempted from all restrictions provided that they have their passports with them.    PCR test requests from Hong Kong, China, Vietnam, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Thailand, South Korea, Japan, United Kingdom, Latvia, Luxembourg, Ukraine, and Estonia to enter Turkey from 15 May 2021. will not be.    Passengers arriving from Brazil and South Africa and arriving in Turkey were suspended temporarily. Passengers from countries other than these countries, who have been in Brazil or South Africa in the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days in a place to be determined by the Turkish official authorities. These passengers will be re-tested on the tenth day of the quarantine period, and their quarantine will be terminated if the test result is negative.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210118205014/http://www.turob.com/tr/haberler/yabanci-turistler-sokaga-cikma-kisitlamasindan-muaf-tutulacaktir    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518094150/https://www.indyturk.com/node/353481/haber/t%C3%BCrsab%E2%80%99dan-i%CC%87%C3%A7i%C5%9Fleri-bakanl%C4%B1%C4%9F%C4%B1-genelgesine-tepki-mant%C4%B1kl%C4%B1-bir-izah%C4%B1-savunulacak    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518095218/https://www.anadolujet.com/en

In terms of economic support, the government doesn't give any support to those who lost their jobs. But those who normally work but because of the covid-19, the firms cannot pay them, for those people there were two options Cash payment support and short-time working allowance/work.     First is Cash payment support which is given to workers who are currently in unpaid time-off (due to covid-19, firms cannot fire the employers, so they are sending their workers to unpaid time-off). In one month its max pay time is 30 days and the daily wage is 47.70 TRY (The currency is changing rapidly in these weeks, so to avoid the wrong amount, I didn't write in USD form). This support is ending on 05/17/2021 if there won't be any extension.     The second way is a short-time working allowance/work. In this payment, the workers who are currently working (who are not in time-off or any other absence situation) and be approved by the Turkish Employment Agency are getting %60 of their daily gross earnings. This support ended on 03/31/2021 but within the new presidential decree, it extended to 06/30/2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210122131003/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/isveren/kisa-calisma-odenegi/genel-bilgiler/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210122191037/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/is-arayan/issizlik-sigortasi/nakdi-ucret-destegi/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210325135853/https://www.cnnturk.com/ekonomi/nakdi-ucret-destegi-ne-zaman-bitiyor-ucretsiz-izin-maas-destegi-ne-zaman-bitecek   http://web.archive.org/web/20210422214717/https://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/haber/resmi-gazetede-yayimlanan-kararla-kisa-calisma-odenegi-3-ay-sureyle-uzatildi-1830299

No changes found. Turkish citizens and residents aged 65 and older are restricted to their place of residence (allowed outside only between 10:00 and 13:00) and Intercity travel permits are required. Additionally, the use of all means of public mass transport in Istanbul has been banned for persons over 65 part of COVID-19 restrictions. On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm. On 11th of February started the vaccination of people over 70 years old. Those over the age of 65, including their spouses over 60, started to receive the vaccine on 12th of February.        Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news, https://web.archive.org/web/20210315180248/https://archive.fo/aKTPz and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315181148/https://archive.fo/yeZZF

Ukraine is under an adaptive quarantine until 30 June 2021 (the quarantine was extended on April 21). As of 30 April, several regions stay in the red zone.   In Kyiv: Starting from Saturday 1 May, the capital Kyiv allows the operation of transport, cafes and restaurants, although passenger and customer numbers will be restricted. Wearing masks is still mandatory in transport and public places. Shopping malls and sports clubs will be able to reopen on 1 May, while schools and kindergartens will open from May 5, local authorities said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503160406/https://www.reuters.com/world/ukraines-capital-kyiv-eases-coronavirus-restrictions-2021-05-01/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210503192825/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19  http://web.archive.org/web/20210503185616/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3238233-covid19-hospitalization-rates-exceeded-in-eight-regions-ministry-of-health.html

The third wave of COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine is over - said the health minister Mr. Stepanov on 7 May. From 8 May, no region is in the red zone, and coding is changed accordingly.   Preschool, school, extracurricular and specialized education is closed if more than 50% of children and staff of the institution are self-isolated (green/yellow/orange zones – therefore coded as general).    http://web.archive.org/web/20210510174541/https://www.ukrinform.net/block-lastnews  http://web.archive.org/web/20210510181449/https://covid19.gov.ua/karantynni-zakhody

No policy change. The 2020/2021 academic year for schoolchildren and students continues in a remote format. The External Independent Evaluation will take place from June 25 to July 17. International students who come to take the exams are exempt from passing observation or self-isolation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515105753/https://covid19.gov.ua/en

Otherwise, the majority of services should be open, including shops, restaurants, cafes, religious establishments, beauty salons and hairdressers, museums, libraries, gyms, fitness centres, swimming pools, hardware stores, cobblers, dentists, auditors, lawyers and notaries (providing appropriate hygiene and distancing measures are in place). Quote: ""Key Policy Responses as of May 6, 2021  To deal with the crisis, Uzbekistan’s government created an Anti-Crisis Fund of US$ 1 billion (about 2 percent of GDP) to fund support to the economy and help those most affected by the crisis. In addition to the Anti-Crisis Fund, the government temporary reduced some taxes and the Fund for Reconstruction and Development increased lending. Specific crisis response measures have included: (i) expanded funding for healthcare, including for medicines, the costs of quarantines, and salary supplements for healthcare works; (ii) an increase in the number of families with children and low-income families receiving social benefits; (iii) assistance to affected businesses via interest subsidies; and (iv) additional public works for infrastructure and to support employment.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210509051406/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No changes found     Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210516204323/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Quote: ""Key Policy Responses as of May 6, 2021  The authorities also temporary reduced social contributions for individual entrepreneurs, postponed the payment of property and land taxes, extended a moratorium on tax audits, and delayed tax declarations for 2019 income taxes. The central government also asked local governments to reduce taxes by 30 percent and provide a grace period on paying property tax.""  Quote: ""The central bank suggested banks defer loan repayments of firms in sectors affected by COVID-19. Subsequently, state-owned banks extended deadlines for loan repayments for affected sectors, including for the national air carrier.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210509051406/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
